RACHEL RAINER. I am the wife of John Rainer, a horse-breaker; I keep a marine store-shop. On a Friday in Sept. Mrs. Clark brought a bundle of twine to me, and asked 3s. 6d. for it—she said, an old lady had sent her with it, who had taken it at a gentleman's house in exchange—I took it to Mr. Cox, next door, went back, and gave Mrs. Clark 2s. for it—I hung it on a nail by the door, and the officer came and took it away.
Prisoner. I have not brought anything to your shop. Witness. You have not been to my shop for three or four months—when you did come I some-times bought of you, and sometimes not.

JOSEPH BENTON (policeman, K 381.) I took the prisoner into custody—I told her it was for a bundle of twine—she took an oath, and said she knew nothing at all about it—in going to the station she said, "Policeman, I will tell you the truth about it; I bought it of a little boy for 1s."—this is the twine.
Prisoner. I did not take an oath; I denied it, because I did no know what to say.

JOHN DALTON
re-examined. This is the sort of twine I lost—I believe it to be mine—the prisoner was in my shop on the Saturday, and wanted some-thing we had not got.
Prisoner. I never was in his shop; I am innocent of the offence; I am a poor destitute creature, and have no friends belonging to me.

GUILTY. Aged 44.—
Confined Six Weeks.

2467.
JOHN MILES and
THOMAS MILES were indicted for
stealing 1 coat, value 15s.; and 1 handkerchief, 3d.; the goods of
Joseph Carter.

JOSEPH CARTER. I live at Victoria-terrace, Stratford. I was working on the railway on Monday morning, the 18th of Oct., I laid my coat on the ground—my handkerchief was in the pocket—my coat was safe at nine o'clock I missed it at ten—John Miles worked there—this is my coat.
ALPRED SCOTT. I am assistant to Mr. Williams, a pawnbroker at Stepney This coat and handkerchief were pawned by Thomas Miles on the 18th of Oct., about the middle of the day.

JOSEPH BENTOS (policeman, K 381.) I took John Miles into custody—just before I took him I saw him give a duplicate to the prosecutor—he said he had pawned the coat, he took it in a drunken spree, and did not think it would come to this.
JOHN MILES. The man is not here who gave me the coat—he took it of and gave it to me, and I pawned it.

ALFRED SCOTT
re-examined. Thomas Miles told me he had given 25s. for it a few weeks before—I have no doubt he is the man—I recollect his face—I said before he was the person—I am confident it was him by his full whiskers—I described him as such.
Thomas Miles. I am not the man that pawned it; I was not there at all; I was at home at eleven o'clock.
(John Miles received a good character.)

JOHN MILES—
GUILTY. Aged 26.—
Confined Three Months.

THOMAS MILES—
NOT GUILTY.
KENT CASES.

2468.
JOHN HOBBS was indicted
for feloniously cutting and wounding
William Smith, on his left side; with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

WILLIAM SMITH. I am a waterman, and live at Deptford—I had known the prisoner about twelve weeks when this matter happened—he keeps a lodging-house, and lets out beds—I had been in the habit of going there. On Monday the 27th of Sept., I was there three different times; in the morning, at two o'clock, and about four or five—I went alone—I stopped about half-an-hour, when I went about four or five—a young woman that lives there took my jacket, which I had taken off at a public-house close by—I went to the prisoner's house for it, and found him standing at the door—I asked him to allow me to go in and get my jacket—he said I should not come into his house any more—I said, "I must come in, or else you go in and get it"—he called the young woman's name two or three times—I said, "I will go in"—I took him by the hand, pulled him away from his own door, and walked into the passage; and as I was in the act of turning into the parlour, I found myself pricked in the left side—I ran out of the house, saw a friend, and discovered a small prick in my side—I thought it was done with a penknife—the hole was very small, and not above three drops of blood came from it—I was taken to a doctor close by, and he put a bit of plaister

on it—he sent me to a surgeon, who probed it—I was able to walk to the office next day—I was not ill above two or three days—I did not see who it was that struck me; it was in the dark passage—there were one or two per
sons outside the door.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You struggle to get into the pri
soner's house, and he did not want you to come in? A. There was not much struggling—I think this might have occurred by accident, if he had a knife in his hand—there was a mat at the door, and he might very likely have stumbled over that—he is not a vindictive man, but very civil and quiet.
COURT. Q. Did you hear him say anything? A. No; he is a man of very few words—I was drinking with him in the morning and afternoon—there was no animosity between us.

HENRY STORER. I am a labourer, at Deptford. On Monday night, the 27th of Sept., I came out of the public-house with Smith—I saw the pri
soner at his own door—Smith wanted to gain an entrance after his jacket—the prisoner said he should not go in, he had been ill-used enough through him, if his jacket was there he would send for it—he called a female, named Lis, three times—there was no answer, and Smith forced the prisoner from the door, and forced his way in; as Smith pushed by him he resisted him, and made a blow at him with something—I do not know that he had anything in his hand—it was between seven and eight o'clock, getting dark; we got a light, and I saw the prisoner in the back room, with this instrument in his hand (a pointed instrument)—he came out of the house shortly after, and I told him he had stabbed Smith—he did not deny it—he said, "If I have, I will stab some one else; lock me up, I want to be locked up"—two or three young men took hold of him, and took him along till they met an officer—in going along he gave this instrument to one of the young men, and said, "It is not a knife, nor a fork, nor a dagger; it is a firmer that I use in my work.
JOHN WILLIAM FORELAND (policeman, R 161.) I took the prisoner into custody—he went very quietly.

THOMAS OAK MITCHELL. I am a surgeon—Smith was brought to my surgery on Monday evening the 27th—I found a punctured wound on the left side of the abdomen—he complained of a good deal of pain, and could not stand upright—I probed the wound, and found it was about three inches deep—it was a dangerous wound—such an instrument as this would cause it—there was also a contused wound over the puncture, which showed that some violence had been used in the infliction of it.

Cross-examine. Q. You said before the Magistrate that it was not a dan
gerous wound? A. Not in itself; but had it taken a straight direction instead of a lateral one, it would have been dangerous—I put some lint on it, and a piece of plaster over it, to keep it on—I brought him through it.

2469.
GEORGE WALTER was indicted
for stealing 51 shillings, the moneys of the
Guardians of the Poor of the Greenwich Union; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

2470.
ALFRED SKAE,
THOMAS HAMMOND , and
JOHN VEN
NELL were indicted for
stealing 6 Knives, value 6s.; the goods of
John Charles Croft Walton; Vennell having been before convicted of felony: to which

SKAE pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 13.—
Confined Six Months and
Whipped.

VENNELL. pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined six months and
Twice Whipped.

MARY ANN EATTEL. I am in the service of John Charles Croft Walton, of No. 4, Deptford-bridge. On the 10th of Sept, the officer came to the shop, and showed me six knives, which I identified as my master's—these are them—they are kept in a case at the bottom of the shop,

JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180.) Between eleven and twelve o'clock, on the 10th of Sept., I saw the three prisoners standing outside the prosecutor's door—Skae went into the shop and then sneaked out, and they all three went away—I followed and took them to the station—I found these knives on Skae—I also found a gold watch, seven silver thimbles, two gold lockets, and a silver box, in the tail of his shirt—I have made every inquiry, but I cannot find the owner of them—the prisoners were all together.

HAMMOND—
GUILTY. Aged 13—
Confined Six Months and
Whipped.

2471.
JAMES M'GREGOR was indicted
for stealing 1 ring, value 2d.; 1 handkerchief, 6d.; 3 shillings, I sixpence, 2 pence, and 5 half-pence; the property of
Ann Parsons, from her person.

ANN PARSONS. I am single, and live at Deptford—I was in the tap-room of the Cricketers public-house on the 6th of Oct.—I had 3s.3. 10 1/2d. in my pocket, and a handkerchief—I fell asleep—I was awoke between three and four o'clock by waiter, and my money, handkerchief, and ring were gone—this is my handkerchief and ring.

Prisoner. Q. Do you know a person named Styles? Q. Yes—I never went to him at the College but twice—I was not drunk—I did not ask you if you would stand a pint of beer—I had money in my pocket—I did not ask you to take the handkerchief and ring up to Styles, nor say he would give you 2d. for it.

CHARLES COOK. I was in the tap-room at the Cricketer's about a quarter past three o'clock that day—I saw Parson's intoxicated—she fell asleep—the prisoner pulled the handkerchief off her neck, and then put his hand into her pocket and then into his own waistcoat-pocket—he dropped one piece of money—he went out—I called the prosecutrix and told her—Smith went after the prisoner.

ROBERT SMITH. I was in the public-house—I saw Parsons come in in
toxicated—the prisoner said he would protect her—some of them were plac
ing a stick on her nose—the prisoner said they should not do it—she west and sat in the corner—the prisoner went to her, and a person made a motion that he was robbing her—I then saw him deliberately take the ring off her finger—he then placed his hand in an indecent way round her petticoats—he left her clothes up, and was going out—a person told him of it—he said he did not know that—he went off, she was woke up, and we followed the pri
soner till he got hear the hospital—she was asking for her handkerchief—he said, "I did not have it"—he pulled out one handkerchief which was not hers—the officer came up, and the prisoner produced another handkerchief, which she said was hers, and I said he had her ring.
HENRY HUGHES (policeman, R 106.) I took the handkerchief and ring
out of the prisoner's possession in the street—he at first said he had no such thing—I took him to the station—I found 7d. on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I never in my life took a single thing from the woman; she put it into my hat; I never offered to meddle with her; she knew me very well; I have never been in custody before.

2472.
HENRY APPLEYARD was indicted
for stealing 1/4 of a pound of tea, value 1s. 6d.; and 1/4 of a pound of tobacco, 1s.; the property of
Ben
jamin Lance, his master.

BENJAMIN LANCE. I keep a shop in Church-street, Greenwich—the pri
soner was in my employ—I lost a sovereign, and desired to search him—he ran up stairs—I caught him by the coat and found on him two parcels—one was tea, and the other tobacco—I suppose they were mine—he told the Ma
gistrate that he removed it with the intention of telling me about it—29s. 6d. was found upon him, and he had borrowed money of me the day before to pay for his washing.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had you a good character with him? A. Yes—his wages were 5s. a week.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2473.
ROSANNA ASHDOWN was indicted
for stealing 1 watch, value 4l.; the goods of
William King Shaw; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Judgment Respited.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2474.
SUSAN PARKER was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign; the moneys of
Richard Humphrey Nunney, from the person of
Susan Nunney.

SUSAN NUNNEY. I am the wife of Richard Humphrey Nunney. On the 15th of Oct., about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was a little tipsy—I laid a sovereign a half-sovereign, and a shilling on the table—the prisoner came in, and soon after the money was gone—I was a little too tipsy to see who took it.

MARY ANN HUNTER. I was at Mrs. Nunney's, in Church-street, Dept-ford, at eleven o'clock in the morning, on the 14th of Oct.—she was a little the worse for liquor—the prisoner came in with two quartern loves from the parish, which she offered to sell for a shilling—Mrs. Nunney said, "Take them home to your children"—she said, "No"—Mrs. Nunney gave her a shilling for them—the prisoner said, "I will send for a pot of beer"—Mrs. Nunney said, "Do as you like about that"—the prisoner then moved and sat down by Mrs. Nunney—she said she had no more than what she had received with the bread.
CHARLES WEBB. On the morning of the 14th of Oct. the prisoner came to me and changed a sovereign, and I saw she had a half-sovereign beside.

CHARLES SEAWOOD (policeman, R 219.) I produce a bundle of new things, which the prisoner said she had bought of her sister—she said she had released the things from pawn with a sovereign she had received of her sister.

Prisoner's Defence. She has been in the habit of buying these loaves of me; I went and sold her these, and I said I would send for a pot of beer; I left her sitting by the fire as drunk as he could be, with three or four women round her.

GUILTY. Aged 39.—
Confined Four Months.

2475.
ELIZA VEINTER was indicted
for stealing 1 ring, value 7s.; and 1 handkerchief, 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Timpson, from his person.

THOMAS TIMPSON. I live at Woolwich. On the 4th of Oct. I had a ring on my finger, and a handkerchief in my pocket—I met the prisoner—she caught me by my hand and asked what I was going to give her—I then had he ring slightly on my finger—she left me, and as soon as she was gone I missed the ring and my handkerchief—these are them.
Prisoner. Q Did you not give me the ring, and want me to go with you? A. No—I did not bring a female who said it was hers.

ENOS CINCH. I am a minister—I had been on duty, and in coming home there was a noise—I stopped to hear what it was—some one said, "There is a ring lost"—while I was there the prisoner dropped this handkerchief with the ring in it from her shawl.
Prisoner's Defence. It does not stand to reason that I could take the ring off his finger.

GUILTY. Aged 32.—
Confined Three Months.

2476.
ELLEN DICKINSON was indicted
for stealing 1 shawl, value 6s., and 1 gown, 5s.; the goods of
William Hudson; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

2477.
ANN CASEY, alias
MARY TAYLOR
, was indicted for
stealing 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
Richard Sears.

RICHARD SEARS. I live in Artillery-place, Woolwich—the prisoner came to my shop on the 28th of Sept., and asked if I had a second-hand shift—she turned and went out—there were two pairs of stockings hanging at the door—after she was gone I missed one pair of them—I went after her, overtook her, and found my stockings on her—these are them.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Have you told us all? A. No—I took the prisoner to the station—she asked me the price of the stockings in the shop—I went after her immediately, and overtook her about 200 yards off, as she was going into a public-house—I cannot recollect exactly how she was dressed—she had a bonnet and shawl on—I pulled that aside and found the stockings under her left arm, loosely doubled up.

GUILTY. Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

2478.
HENDERSON WILLIAM ELLIS was indicted
for stealing 1 mahogany bracket, value 1s.; and 2 pieces of mahogany, 1s.; the goods of our
Lady the Queen.

CAHRLES FREDRICK FIELD. I am inspector of the police in Woolwich Dock-yard. On the 28th of Sept. I was on duty there—the men left about half-past five o'clock that day—the prisoner was a confidential man, and was the last man who was left to see that the fires were out—he was the last man that evening and he came and brought his keys to hang up in my presence—as he hung up his keys I perceived something move under his coat—I said

to him, "Mr. Ellis, I think you are wrong to-night; come into my office, I must search you"—I put my hand under his coat and found this bracket, which was what had attracted my attention—I said, "Where did you get this?"—he said, "I made it in the yard"—then said I "It is the Queen's property"—"Yes," said he "it is "—I said, "I shall detain this, and report it to the Commodore—I afterwards saw the Commodore's-secretary—the pri
soner's house was afterwards searched.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Had you seen the prisoner at work that day? A. No—the Government employ him—there is a foreman over him in the shop he worked in, whose name I think is Hall—I do not know what the prisoner had been working at that day—I am not a judge of wood—I should say this is mahogany, I will not swear it—the prisoner was employed as a carpenter, as other persons about there are—I do not know whether they make such things as this in the carpenter's department.

DAVID ROY. I am a clerk in the Dock-yard at Woolwich. This is what they call mahogany in the yard—the prisoner was a carpenter there, and he has been in the employ seven or eight years—it was his duty to lock up the carpenter's place of work—it was no part of his duty to take any of the wood away—he had no leave or licence to make any bracket and take it away—such a thing might be made for the use of the yard; but what he makes in the yard is by the order of those above him.

Cross-examined. Q. Supposing it were not quite finished, had he no business to take it home? A. No—the carpenters and persons employed there do not, from time to time, take work home to finish it there—they are never detected doing it—if they do, it is against order—I cannot swear they do not—the store-keeper pays the prisoner—he is employed under Captain Beacbey—he had 3s. or 3s. 6d. a day.—there is extra work from time to time, and they are paid additionally for it—I should rather say the carpen
ters are not paid by the job—I cannot say whether Mr. Hall or Captain Beachey hired the prisoner—he was immediately under Captain Beachey's orders.

2479.
HENDERSON WILLIAM ELLIS was again indicted
for unlaw-fully having in his custody and possession certain naval stores, the pro
perty of our
Lady the Queen.

CHARLES FREDERICK FIELD. I am inspector of the police at Woolwich Dock-yard—the prisoner worked there as a carpenter, and, I understand, for seven or eight years. On the 28th of Sept., as he was hanging up his keys, I per
ceived something move under his coat, and I said, "Mr. Ellis, I think you are wrong to night"—I found on him a mahogany bracket—On the next morning he came to work at seven o'clock—I said to him, "You are my prisoner; I must send a man to search your house"—I sent Fisher at seven o'clock, and finding he did not return I sent Wootton at eleven—I went myself after I had taken him into custody, about half-past eleven o'clock—I found property there containing the Queen's mark, in a little bit of a cellar by the kitchen—I think it is a place where he sometimes worked—I produce the things—the constable had found them, and they were all lying there when I went—there are some brass hinges and other articles, all marked with the broad arrow—after I had found them, I went back and saw the prisoner at the

station—I said, "Ellis, we have found a great quantity of things in your house belonging to Government," and I showed him the things which we had brought there—he said, "Good God! I must have been mad to have taken them,"

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Is this the account you have always given of what he said? A. I think it is—he said he must have been mad, or something to that purpose—this is my signature to this deposition—(the witness's deposition being read, it contained this expression, "I am a very foolish man; I must have been out of my mind.")

Q. Do you find one word about having taken them? A. It tantamounts to the same thing; "I have been a very foolish man to have taken them"—I found these articles on a board in the cellar—I never knew that the prisoner lived there till he told me—I do not think his father is alive, I do not know—there is a Mrs. Clayton lives in the house—I do not know that there is a mate of the prisoner's living there—we only saw Mrs. Clayton—I did not see these articles taken from any place—they were already out—some of them are old, the greater part are new.

BENJAMIN FISHER (policeman, 272 R.) On Wednesday, the 29th of Sept., I went by the direction of the inspector to the prisoner's house, 35, St. Mary-street, Woolwich—the prisoner showed me the house—I asked him if he lived there, he said, "Yes"—I asked which were his rooms—he took me to the parlour, and from the parlour to the bed-room, and in the bed-room I found a few screws which have the appearance of being new, these are them—I then went down to the kitchen, and in a cellar I found a large box with a number of drawers in it, and almost every drawer had some
thing in it—these sixteen keys were hanging up in the cellar—almost every key is marked—the prisoner was by at the time—I found in that cellar, or coal-shed, these brass articles in a drawer by the side of the chest and some nails in the chest, all marked with the arrow—I found in the chest a latch and staples which have the broad arrow on them, and this file with the broad arrow on it—I asked the prisoner if the chest belonged to him—he said, "Yes"—he afterwards said it was his father's—I asked who occupied that room, he told me that the woman who was there occupied it—he then said he occupied it, and she did not, only for the use of cooking—I was a consider
able time looking over the box of nails—then Mr. Wootton came, and he made a second search at the time I was gone to the Dock-yard to acquaint Mr. Field—I came back with Mr. Field, and assisted in bringing the things away—I took them to the Dock-yard, and they have been in the possession of Mr. Field—at the time the things were found, the prisoner was walking about, crying, and saying he was a foolish fellow, and he wanted me to give him the things that the might throw them away—his wife was there at the time, and begged me to do it—I said I could not do anything of the kind, I had my duty to perform.

Cross-examined. Q. He seemed in great distress? A. Yes—he and his wife and children live in the bed-room—the screws I found in the bed-room are not marked—the other articles new and old were found in the chest in the cellar—I know the prisoner by seeing him go in and out of the yard to his work, that is all—Mrs. Clayton uses the kitchen—there was a bench in the kitchen, and he used it as a workshop—I have passed the house, but I never knew the prisoner lived in it—I should say the chest had not been opened for three or four months—it was entirely a tool chest—it looked very dusty—there were two doors to the cellar, and no window.

CHARLES WOOTTON (policeman, 276 R.) I went to the prisoner's house on the 29th Sept., I found Fisher there—I searched part of the premises, and behind some brickwork, under the rafters, I found a great quantity of brass and iron articles concealed—I found a few nails in a basket in the small cellar place—part of the things I found were old, but they are mostly new.

Cross-examined. Q. Was this lock found there? A. Yes—it was behind the brick-work which supported the rafters under the stairs—I put my arm in and there was a lower place where these things were—it was a dark place.

CATHERINE CLAYTON. I have lodged in the prisoner's house about three months—I have one room entirely, and the use of the kitchen when I want it to boil my kettle—nobody else lived in the house but Mr. Ellis, and his wife and three children—I think his father has been dead five years—I never knew of this property till I saw the officers find it.

Cross-examined. Q. You never saw the chest opened? A. No—it stood in a dark place—I never saw any use made of it—there was a mate of the prisoner's lived there, but he went away, and I had his room—I have known the prisoner six years, he bore an excellent character—his father was a builder—I have heard that the chest was his father's

DAVID ROY. I am a clerk in the store-keeper's office in Woolwich Dock-yard. Some of these articles are old—these others are new—these nails and this lock have never been used, nor these other articles—these are all marked with the broad arrow as being the property of Her Majesty, and are all new—I have known the prisoner four or five years—I believe he has been seven or eight years in the establishment—it is no part of his duty as a carpenter to take away any of these things—if he had occasion to use articles of this description, he was bound to use them in the yard.

Cross-examined. Q. These things would not be in the carpenter's depart
ment? A. Yes—all of them.
MR. HALL. of the Dock-yard, Woolwich, gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY. Aged 41.—
Confined Six Months.

2480.
SARAH WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 4 1/2 lbs of bacon, value 3s. 6d.; the property of
Stephen Winder.

STEPHEN WINDER. I am a grocer and cheesemonger, at Greenwich. On the 20th of Oct. I saw the prisoner take a piece of bacon of 4 1/2 lbs weight from the window, and put it under her cloak—she went across the road—I went after her, and in taking the bacon from her she dropped it—this is it—it is my property, and the piece I saw her take.
Prisoner. I hope you will have mercy on me.

GUILTY.—
Confined Three Months.

2481.
JOHN GREEN was indicted
for stealing 1 loaf, value 6d.; the goods of
Alfred Stansfield; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 19.—
Confined Seven Days.

2482.
ROBERT TANNER was indicted
for embezzling 1l. 7s. 8d., which he had received on account of the
guardians of the poor of the Wand
worth and Clapham Union; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 56.—Recommended to mercy .—
Confined Four Months
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)

2483.
HANNAH WILLIAMS
was indicated for feloniously cutting and wounding
James Newbold, on the neck and throat, with intent to murder him.—2nd COUNT, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JAMES NEWBOLD. I am a hammer-man, in service, at Rotherhithe—I kept company with the prisoner for some months—I have ceased to do so since Eas
ter. On Monday, the 13th of Sept., I was at a beer-shop, in Rotherhithe-street—somebody brought me a message, and I went outside the house, and found the prisoner—she said the believed I was going to be married to another—I said I was—she said I should not—I told her she could not hinder it—she said she would, she would have her revenge either on me or the young lady—I said if she did, I would knock her d—d head off—I left her, went back into the house, and in about half an hour went out, and saw her again—she said she house, and in about half an hour went out, and saw her, went back towards my master's shop—she followed me towards the gates—I told her to follow me no further, if she did I would knock her d—d head off—no more words passed—I saw her make a cut at me, and felt a knife go across my throat—I bled, I went to a surgeon, and had my wound dressed.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was not she in respectable service when you first made her acquaintance? A. I believe she was—I believe I prevailed on her to submit to my wishes—I used to go to see her at her master's—I borrowed no money of her; she gave it me, to take my clothes out of pawn—that was not because I had nothing but rags to cover me—sometimes she found me in food—I have been asked why I did not marry her—I did not answer "I have had connection with her, and it is not likely that I should marry her"—no such word ever passed out my mouth—words might have been said about marriage, but I did not promise her—I cannot say whether those words were said before I got possession of her person—on the day in question, she came to me at the public-house where I was at dinner—I left her outside, and went to my dinner—when I came out, in half an hour, I found her still waiting—she was in tears—I told her that my mates were staring at us, and if she did not go away I would knock her d—d head off—I did not raise my hand; I did nothing, I had my hands in my pocket—I did not intend to strike her—I did not see a knife in her hand—I did not see people outside the public-house eating bread and cheese—I do not know where the knife came from—I was close to her when I said I would knock her d—d head off—I then moved away towards the gates, and then she made the blow at me with the knife—I went to a surgeon's, and got it sown up, and a plaister put on it—I did not go to work again—the surgeon said I could not—I am very sorry to prosecute her—I never wished to do her any harm—I cannot marry her.

GEORGE GARRETT. I am a hammer-man, employed in the same factory as Newbold. On Monday, the 13th of Sept., I had my dinner with him—we left the public-house together—I saw the prisoner as I came out—I saw her

and Newbold talking together, but did not hear what they said—he went on towards the gates—she followed him, saying something to him—he would not stop to listed to her, and I saw her a knife out of her pocket, and cut his throat—he was not bleeding much when I saw him—I believe there was a great deal of blood afterwards—I laid of the prisoner—she went with me—the knife fell on the pavement, and the policeman brought it to the station—it was very much like this—(produced.)

Cross-examined. Q. Were there people outside as well as inside the public-house taking the refreshment, and eating their dinners? A. Yes—he was a few paces before her—she was following him, and I was a few yards behind—I heard nothing that was said.

PHILIP DONOVAN (policeman, M 208.) I was in Rotherhithe-street on the 13th of Sept., and met Garrett with the prisoner in his charge—he handed her over to Miller, who was with me—I produce the knife, which I received from the landlord of the public-house.

JAMES MILLER (policeman, M 222.) I received the prisoner in charge from Garrett—in going to the station she said, in answer to some questions by the crowd, that she had brought the knife with her, in her pocket, from her mistress's house—I do not know where her mistress lived.

BENJAMIN ACKLAND. I am a surgeon, at Rotherhithe. On Saturday, the 13th of Sept., the prosecutor was brought to me—I found a wound on the left side of his neck, nearly six inches long, and extending two and a half inches below the ear to the centre of the chin—in one place it was nearly half an inch deep—it was not a dangerous wound—it was a flesh wound—a knife would produce it—I attended him for about three weeks—he went on favourably.

Cross-examined. Q. You put some plaister on it, did you not? A. I stitched it up, and put plaister on it—it was unhealthy at first, which was the reason of its requiring longer attendance—that might be caused by the man's being given to drink.

JAMES NEWBOLD
re-examined. I was in company with the prisoner four days before this happened, and had been out with her—I was more than two months out of work, during which time she rendered me what assistance she could.
COURT. Q. Where did her mistress live? A. Near Kennington-common.

GUILTY
of an assault. Aged 20.—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined One Month

2484.
CHARLES CROMWELL HICKS was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged warrant for the payment of 7l. 10s., with intent to defraud
Robert Simpson.

ROBERT SIMPSON. I am a baker, in the Walworth-road. On Monday, the 6th of Sept., the prisoner came and asked me to change this check—(pro
duced)—it is for 7l. 10s.—he said 3l. 10s. would do—I had known him for two months—I asked him why he had not got it changed—he said it was too late, and he was very much in want of the money—it was about six o'clock in the evening—I asked who he had it from—he pointed to the check, and said, "That gentleman is my uncle; he is a rich old fellow, with about 200,000l.; if you were to see him in the street, you would think he was not worth 200 pence; and if he were to see me in the street, he would say, there is a penny for you, and be off with you"—(check read—"London, Sept. 8th,

1847. On demand, pay bearer 7l. 10s., placing the same to the account of R. Hicks, Esq., and believe me your obedient servant, C. Hicks. To S. Pratt, Esq., Messrs. Vacher and Sons, Parliamentary Agents, 39, Parliament-street, Whitehall.")—I could not see which name he pointed to when he spoke about the rich uncle—I pointed to the name of Pratt, and asked who he was—he said he was a Parliamentary agent—I let him have 3l. 10s.—he said, "I suppose I must put my name on the back of the check"—he put this on it—this is it—it looks like "H. Hicks"—he said nothing when he wrote it—he gave it to me, and said I might either pay it away, or he would give me the money next day—he did not come next day—I sent my wife with a message—she returned with the check—in consequence of that I went to the prisoner's lodging—I was his baker—I did not find him till the Thurs
day following—I then told him there were no effects to the check, and I must give him into custody—he said I did he was a ruined man, but he could not be worse off than what he was, it would be a charity to do it—I gave him in charge.

Prisoner. Q. What was the state of the light when I endorsed it? A. It was perfectly daylight—I am quite sure you said "uncle," and not "father"—I saw your wife at your lodging—it did not rain all day the day after—I did not purpose to you to give security after giving you in charge in my own shop, and say that would answer my purpose just as well—the man who ac
companied me to the station was not a policeman—he is not here.
COURT. Q. Do you recollect what words you made use of when he asked you to give him the money on the check? A. No, but I am quite sure I asked him where he got the check from.

THOMAS PRATT. I am an army agent at 35, King-street, Westminster—I lived at 29, Parliament-street, at Messrs. Vacher and Sons, many years, and left three years ago—I had chambers there—I never saw the prisoner but twice before—I knew his father very well—he died three weeks ago—I kept his accounts for many years—his name was Raymond Hicks—he was as officer in the army, and I received his pay as an agent—I never knew of the prisoner's having an uncle—I had an account of the father in Sept.—I had no instructions to pay anything to the account of C. Hicks or J. H. Hicks—I do not know whose writing this check is, it is not the prisoner's father's—in the spring of this year the prisoner called on me to inquire after his father's health—I think that was the first time I saw him—I do not think I have ever paid any money to him on his father's account—this check was offered to me, and I returned it.

Prisoner. Q. Were you my father's agent in 1831? A. No, Mr. Vacher was—I lived there at that time—I am not aware of a sum of money being paid to your father's account at the decrease of a half-sister, Miss Harriet Hicks, about that time—I do not think that four checks for 60l., 40l., 15l. and 10l. passed through Mr. Vacher's books at that period by a letter of advice of your drawing—I was told at that time this check was written your father was very ill—I heard that he was not in a condition to have written—I did not see him—I believe he died a few days after you were taken in charge—I am not aware that Mrs. Hicks afterwards paid the amount to this cheek.

JOHN MAY (policeman, V 281.) Mr. Simpson gave the prisoner into my charge—he said, "I will willingly go"—on the way to the station he was I should do him justice to take a rope and tie him up to the lamp-post, for he was in great distress, and he and his wife had had nothing to eat nut bread and water for the last fortnight—he said, "I received the 3l. 10l. of Mr. Simpson, with a view that I should be able to pay it again in two or three days, but not
being able to realize sufficient money from a book which I am publishing; this is the result."

THOMAS JOHN KING. I live in Lothbury, I have known the prisoner three years, and have seen him write several times—to the best of my belief this instrument is in writing." [The prisoner, in a long address, stated that he had been reduced from afflu
ence to great distress, and had been compelled to support himself as an author; that he wrote the order in question to obtain a sum of money to complete and print a work which he had translated, and which was patronized by many emi
nent persons; but that t was drawn upon his father, who owed him 10l., and not upon his uncle.]

GUILTY. Aged 52.—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Transported for Sven Years

2485.
CHARLES CROMWELL HICKS was again indicted
for unlaw
fully obtaining 2 sovereigns and 1 half-sovereign, from
William Selwood, by false pretences.

WILLIAM SELWOOD. I am a grocer, and live in Belgrave-place, Wands
worth-road—the prisoner dealt with me some short time before the 28th of Aug. for grocery—he came into my shop on Saturday, the 28th, about four o'clock, produced this check, and said it was too late to go to Charing-cross that night to get it cashed, if I could cash it he would be very much obliged to me, and I could pay it away on Monday morn
ing, if I liked—(read—"London, Aug. 28th, 1847.—Gentlemen, pay to myself or order the sum of 2l. 10s., as per advice from Lient-Col. car
ruthers. C. HICKS. To Messrs. Cox and Greenwood's, army agents, Craig's-court, Charing-cross.")—I asked him who it was drawn on—he said on Col. Carruthers, payable at Cox and Greenwood's, Charing-cross—he said Col. Carruthers owed him 15l., and he could only get leave to draw on him for that small amount—he said that the colonel was an old acquaintance of his—I gave him the money for the check, 2l. 10s., and in the course of a few days I paid it away to Mr. Underwood, the tea-dealer—the prisoner called on me again on the Monday evening, and asked me if I had paid the check away—I said I had not, I should pay it away in the course of a day or two—he said, "Very well"—he did not say anything farther then, but I think there was some talk about his knowing Col. Carruthers many years in the army—I do not remember what he said—I saw him next on the Saturday morning—he asked me if I had paid the check away—I told him I had—he said very well, he expected it would be paid—he came again the same day, and asked me if I had heard anything about the check—I told him I had not, and he said he did not want me to be a loser by it, and there was 2l. of the money, and threw down two sovereigns—I told him I could not take the two sovereigns, as I had not got the check—he took the sovereigns up, and went off—I received a letter the same day from Mr. Underwood—I have it here—I sent for the prisoner about six o'clock the same evening, and showed him the letter—he read it—(letter read—"11, James-street, Covent-garden. Dear Sir,—We have presented the check this morning at Cox and Co., being the place appointed and they say they have not any orders from Col. Carruthers to pay it; should there be any mistake in it, please to let us know as soon as convenient. Yours respectfully, J. PEARCE for Mr. Underwood. Sept. 4, 1847.")—after reading that letter the prisoner said he would write to Col. Carruthers about it—he then went away—he came to my shop again on the

Monday, and said he had got a letter from Col. Carruthers, and if it was pre
sented any time after the following Wednesday it would be cashed—I said I hoped it would, I dare say my friend was not in any hurry for a few days, so I wrote to Mr. Underwood—the prisoner went away, and I did not see him after that till he was taken into custody on the following Thursday—I said nothing to him them.

Prisoner. Q. Do you not recollect that I spoke of Col. Carruthers' bro
ther as owing me 15l., and not the colonel? A. I understood you to say Col. Carruthers—I gave you 2l. 10s. in cash, and you had goods to the amount of about 7s. or 8s. at the time—you did not say you had any doubts about it being paid.
CHARLES OAKES. I am clerk at Cocks and Greenwood's—Col. Carruthers keeps an account with us—we had no authority at all to pay this check—we refused it—it have no knowledge of the prisoner.

Prisoner. Q. Are you not in the habit of paying money to the signature of persons who you do not know, on receiving a letter of advise from one of your clients, that is, if Colonel Carruthers had written a note? A. We do certainly pay money on receiving a letter of advice—I have no knowledge of you as having been a client of our house for some years.

Prisoner's Defence. I was a cadet at the Military College with Colonel Carruthers and a brother of his in 1818 and 1819; I met his brother at a levee of the Horse Guards with other officers; we dined together, and he borrowed from me 15l., promising to repay me; I never thought of it or heard from him since; latterly I have been obliged to live by my pen, and have published several works by subscription, which have been supported chiefly by military officers, who were cadets; I saw an account of the arrival of Colonel Car
ruthers, and of his regiment receiving colours from another old college friend of mine, Lord Fredrick Fitzclarence; I wrote to the Colonel, telling him how circumstances were changed with me, mentioning the loan to his brother, and asking him to take a copy of my book, and that if I did not hear from him in ten days I should take the liberty of drawing on Cox and Greenwood on his account, for 2l. 10s., the amount of my book, and he would then perhaps see what he could do for me as to his brother's debt; receiving no answer I did as the prosecutor has stated; I have perhaps acted foolishly, but I had not the slightest intention of cheating Mr. Selwood, or doing wrong to any one.

GUILTY. Aged 52.—
Confined One Month.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

2486.
EDWARD JONES was indicted
for a rape on
Ann Eliza Pipe.

GUILTY. Aged 27.—
Confined Two Years.

2487.
THOMAS HARRIS was indicted
for feloniously sending to
Emma Sanders a letter, demanding certain goods from her, with menaces, and without any reasonable or probable cause; to which he pleaded

GUILTY.—
To enter into recognizance.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner, upon which Ms. PARRY offered no evidence.)

2488.
ALFRED PRATT was indicted
for unlawfully breaking and en
tering the dwelling-house of
Jane Johnson, with intent to steal.

HENRY JOHNSON. I am a clerk, and live with my mother at St.
George's-row, New Kent-road, St. Mary, Newington. On the 9th of Oct. I left my home about half-past six in the morning—I am quite sure I left the door quite close after me—it has a common spring lock—my mother and brothers were in the house—no one was up—I do not know the prisoner.

THOMAS HEATH. I am a warehouseman at 20, St. George's-row, opposite Mrs. Johnson's—on the 9th of Oct., about a quarter before seven o'clock—I saw the prisoner make several attempts to enter the house at the door—it was some time before he could do so, as people were frequently passing—I saw him trying the key-hole several times—he saw some one coming along and came to the front of the house, went to the door again, put his hand to the lock, and appeared to be forcing an entrance—I saw him go in—I went down stairs and went over—the door was put too but not fastened—I just went over the threshold, and saw the prisoner in the passage close the par
lour-door, I laid hold of him, sent got a constable, and gave him in charge.

GEORGE BASS (policeman.) I received information, and went to the passage, found the prisoner, and took him in charge—Health had got him by the collar—I took these two chisels from him—I took him in the station—as he went he said he went to make water against the door.
COURT. Q. Was he found inside? A. Yes.

GUILTY
of Entering with intent to Steal. Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.

2489.
THOMAS HARVEY and
THOMAS BLACKMAN were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Crisp, about one in the night of the 11th of Oct., at
Bermondsey, with intent to steal,

WILLIAM NOAKES (policeman, M 104.) I know Mr. Crisp's premises in Bermondsey-wall, in the parish of Bermondsey—I was on duty there on Tuesday morning, the 12th of Oct., about one o'clock, or a little later, I tried the gate of the premises, it opens into a yard which leads to the back of the counting-house—I saw a pair of steps places against the counting-house win
dow, which was open—I went up the steps, looked in, and saw everything strewed about in confusion—a cheat of drawers was drawn out close to the door, so that nobody could get in at the door—it is a door leading from the counting-house to the dwelling house—I came down the steps, turned on my light, and saw the two prisoners lying down on a hen-coop beneath some shrubs, striving to conceal themselves—I had known them both well before—they both jumped up and ran into another corner of the yard—I turned my light on them both again—they found they could not get away, and I secured Harvey—Blackman escaped—I called him by name as he was getting over the fence—Harvey said, "It is not much of the case, the window was open before I came"—I took him to the station-house—I afterwards examined the counting-house window, and found there had been some small instrument put underneath to force it up—there were no sash-lines to it, so that it required some force to get it up—next morning I searched the yard and found this letter lying in the direction in which Blackman had escaped over the fence—it was within a few yards of the fence.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. The moment you turned your light on they ran away to another part of the yard? A. Yes—the window was up as high as it could go.

THOMAS CRISP. I live in Mill-street, Bermondsey, and am a shipwright—my dwelling-house adjoins the counting-house—they are not under the same roof, but it all adjoins—there is a door from one to other—the officer knocked me up on the morning of the 12th of Oct. at half-past one—I went to the street-door and spoke to him, and then went to get into the counting-house, but the door was barricaded up with a chest of drawers, so that I could not get it—the chest of drawers had been in their place the night before, close by the door—I had been in the room at a quarter to seven in the evening before, and left my son there—he us here—when I found I could not get in that way, I came out at the street-door, called up my foreman, and ultimately went into the counting-house by the window—I found it in a state of confusion—some one had been there—this letter produced is a letter from one of my captains from Calcutta—it had been in one of the drawers with others.

Cross-examined. Q. There was a pair of steps against the window! A. Yes, and the lower sash of the window was open—the counting-house is a part of the dwelling-house—the roof is a lean-to—there is a door from the dwelling-house to the counting-house—I have one entrance to the counting-house from the yard, and another from the private house.
THOMAS WILLIAM CRISP. I am the prosecutor's son—I was in the counting-house on Monday night, the 11th, after my father—I left at seven o'clock—I locked it up—the window was shut down and fastened.

Cross-examined. Q Is the dwelling-house yours or your father's? A. My father's—I am not in partnership with him—my brother is—he lives in East-lane, some distance from there—my father, mother, and the servants live in the house—my brother does not.

JAMES THARM. I live with my mother in Providence-buildings, Ber
mondsey. I know both the prisoners—they used to lodge with my mother—they did not lodge on the night of the burglary, the 11th of Oct.—they did the night before—I saw them on the Monday night, between seven and eight o'clock, at the Ship A-ground, within 150 yards of Mr. Crisp's, and I saw them there about twelve, and asked them if they were coming home—one of them said,:No"—next morning about seven o'clock I saw Blackman by my bedside at my mother's—that was after the police had been to my mother's—he asked me what had been the matter—I told him that Harvey was taken into custody, I was told, for breaking into Mr. Crisp's pre
mises—he did not say anything, but walked down stairs, and went away—he never came back to my mother's after that—I saw no more of him till he was in custody.

Cross-examined. Q. how do you get your living? A. By work when I can get it—that is not very seldom—I was at work about a month or two before this—I can play the violo—I do not get my living by it at public-houses—I do play occasionally—I was not playing the fiddle at the Ship a-ground—I was at the Tailor's Arms, in Shad Thames on this night—I know a per
son named Tracey—I saw the prisoners and Tracey at the Ship a-ground, all three of them during the evening—Tracey and Blackman both came to me next morning—Tracey came first, about half an hour before Blackman—I swear Blackman came—I swear all three were at the Ship a-ground—I was in custody myself once for the month, for being out of a night—my mother gave me into custody—my brother came home tipsy one evening, and broke

my violin, and I came out and swore I would not come into the house again, my mother sent the policeman after me, and Mr. Cottingham sent me to prison because I would not come home—they said nothing else against me—I was never given into custody for anything else—I have been at a station once besides for being out of a night—I last saw Tracey on the morning he came to my bedside—I had not known him more than nine months before.

WILLIAM FORDHAM (policeman, M 262.) In consequence of information I looked for Blackman, and on the 18th of Oct. found him in the Old Kent-road, he was on one side, and I on the other—as soon as he saw me he ran away—I pursued him for about half an hour, came up to him, and stopped him in the New-road which leads into the Deptford-road, and into Bermondsey—he asked what I wanted him for—I told him for being concerned in a burglary at Mr. Crisp's—he said he knew nothing about it.
Harvey's Defence. I was out, and went down there, and thought it was a shed to sleep in.

HARVEY—
GUILTY. Aged 19.

BLACKMAN—
GUILTY. Aged 21.

2490.
LOUISA VINCENT was indicted
for feloniously cutting and wounding
Thomas Soarston, on the left side of his head, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

THOMAS SOARSTON. I am a carpenter, and live in Kendall-street, New Cross, Deptford. I know the prisoner—I believe the child she has now in her arms to be mine—I have contributed to its maintenance ever since it has been born—I have allowed her 3s. 6d. a-week until I was had up at the Court, and then I was to pay half-a-crown a-week—I lived with her two years ago, for about eighteen months—I have left her nearly two years—the child is twelve months old next May—she would never keep away from me—she has been to my lodgings several times—the last time she came was a month ago yesterday, between eight and nine in the morning—she knocked at the door, and I answered her—she said I was the party she wished to see—I said, "Whatever you do be quiet"—she rushed into the kitchen, and began knocking me about as well as she was able—after that she was quiet, and I thought she was going away quietly—the child was with her—she put it down under the table, and began violently to assault me as far as laid in her power, after which the child was taken away by the neighbours—I thought she was then going away quietly, when she struck me with the poker—she had hit me with the rolling-pin previously, but I do not make any complaint about that—she struck me with the poker on the forehead—she said she should not mind being hanged for me—I cannot say the exact words she used.

Prisoner. He beat me with the rolling-pin, and I struck him in my own defence; he knocked me down; whilst on my back he put his left hand round me, and tried to strangle me; he took up the rolling-pin and nearly broke my arm; I was very much bruised. Witness. It was some consider
able time after that she struck me with the poker—there were some blows exchanged on both sides with the rolling-pin—she first came between eight and nine—as near as I can recollect, she staid altogether about twenty minutes—she struck me first with getting the better of me—she is a powerful person.

Prisoner. I went for my money—I was without victuals four days. Wit
ness.

She had three week's money due to her at the time—I did not hit her particularly hard—it was not harder on one side than the other—she hit me as hard as she could, and perhaps just in the moment of excitement I hit her as hard as I could—I did not have a surgeon to attend to the wound, but I have the mark of it.

WILLIAM MORCOMB. I heard the disturbance, but did not see the begin
ning of it.

SAMUEL COPPING (policeman.) About nine o'clock, on the 25th of Sept. the prosecutor came to me, I looked at his head where he was cut—blood was flowing down each side of his cheek—I found a large cut on his forehead—I put my finger on it, and pressed the wound down, and it did not come up again—I told him to go to the doctor—he did not go—the prisoner was not there then—she was in a beer shop opposite—I went there to her, and told her she was my prisoner for cutting a man's head open with a poker—she said, "It serves him right, I mean it"—she said nothing about being beaten with the rolling-pin, or about any scuffle between them.

Prisoner. I told him I had been very much beaten—I did not know whe
ther I could carry the child to the station for my arms were so bruised about.

Witness. When she got about a mile towards the station, she said, "My arm is bruised, and I can hardly carry the child, "but when I took her she never said a word—she pulled up her sleeve at the station, but I could not see any bruises.
Prisoner. A woman named Martha Davis saw the bruises about me, and promised to bring my bonnet here to show.

(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that the prosecutor, after pre
missing her marriage, had induced her to live with him, telling her that his wife was transported; that after some time he wished her to obtain money by pros
titution, which she refusing he deserted her, agreeing to allow her something for the child; that she went to him for the money, when he knocked her down and ill-used her, and all she did was in her own defence.)

MARTHA DAVIS. I remember the day when the prisoner was apprehended on this charge—I was with her the whole of the day—I saw her when she came back from the prosecutor's—she was bruised very much on her arm and sides—she showed me the bruises—she appeared to have been beaten.

THOMAS SOARSTON
re-examined. I am a married man.

2491.
CHARLES FRANK COMBE was indicted
for a robbery on
Charles Soper, putting him in fear, and stealing from his person, and against his will, 2 sovereigns, his moneys, and beating, striking, and using other personal violence to him.

CHARLES SOPER. I am clerk to Mr. Knapp, a barrister, and live at No. 1, Walcot-square, Lambeth. On Saturday night, the 9th of Oct., I was at the Cornwall Arms, Cornwall-road, and saw the prisoner there—I asked if he would go of an errand for me to Princes-street—he went, and returned in twenty minutes—there were several persons there besides the prisoner, but he was drinking with two in particular—I had to change half-a-sovereign for the purpose of his going on the errand—he saw me do that—I paid for two pints of ale, which he drank the best part of—I gave him 6d. for going on the errand—he said I had given the landlord a sovereign instead of a half-sovereign, and told me to look—I put my hand into my pocket, found my

money all right, and said, "No"—I had about 2l. 10s., and a few halfpence—that was at about eight o'clock—I had gone there purposely to meet a friend—I left the house about a quarter to nine, or nine o'clock, and went towards my friend's house, where I had sent the prisoner with the message—(he had returned with word that he would be at home in an hour, and that was my object in waiting at the public-house)—as I was going along I put my hand in my pocket, to see that I had my cash all right, and I put my gold in one pocket, and my silver in the other—it was all right—I went to my friend's house, stood talking there five or ten minutes, and then went towards Broadwall and St. Saviour's workhouse, in a direct line to my own home—it rained very fast—the prisoner came up to me close by St. Saviour's workhouse—he was alone—he walked by my side, and thinking he was one of Mr. Maudslay's men, I introduced the subject of the late fire—I am posi
tive it was the prisoner—he hit me in the mouth with his fist, thrust, his hand into my pocket, and tripped me up, by putting his leg between mine—whether he took my money while I was falling or not I do not know, but my gold was gone directly I got up, and my pocket turned inside out—when I got up I saw the prisoner running under the lamp—I called out, "Stop thief!" as well as I could, but I had not much breath in my body—I had never been to this public-house but once before, and that was with my friend.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Who was this friend? A. Mr. Edgcombe, the owner of the house—I had left chambers at four o'clock—I had been drinking—I had paid for four pints of pale ale between four and seven o'clock—I had no spirits—I had a pint of half-and-half, with some bread and cheese—I have a perfect recollection of everything that took place—I was quite sober when the prisoner knocked me down—I had nothing but the two pints of ale in the Cornwall Arms, and the prisoner drank nearly the whole of that—I was there about three quarters of an hour, or an hour altogether—I was not drinking with any one but the prisoner, neither did I speak to any person—the landlord turned the prisoner out of the parlour—I had not invited him in—he followed me in and sat by my side, and the land
lord requested him to go out—I had never seen him before—he followed me from the Cornwall Arms—I cannot say I was sober—I was certainly not drunk—I was sober when he knocked me down—it sobered me—the per
spiration ran from me—this occurred not a quarter of a mile from my friend's house—I had not been talking twenty minutes there—I was talking to Sarah Blake at my friend's house for about the minutes—she was no friend of mine—I had never seen her before—I walked from the Cornwall Arms to Princes-street.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You sent a man with a message whom you say was the prisoner? A. Yes—I am sure it was the person I sent with the message that knocked me down—I saw him by the light at St. Saviour's workhouse.

JOHN PRETTY. I am landlord of the Cornwall Arms. On Saturday, the 9th of Oct., Soper was at my house eight o'clock—I saw the prisoner there—I had seen him several times before, and am confident he is the man—I saw Soper send him on a message to Mr. Edgcombe, and saw him return—Soper went into the parlour, and the prisoner followed him—I followed them into the parlour, not thinking that the prisoner was properly dressed for my parlour.
Cross-examined. Q. I suppose parlour is frequented by respectable

tradesmen? A. Yes, and I did not think him fit company—he did not go in by Soper's invitation, he followed him in—Soper had two pints of six-penny ale—I ordered the prisoner out of the parlour—he asked Soper to come with him, and he followed him out of the parlour—Soper was the worse for liquor—they both left my house in company together.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did Soper appear to be drunk? A. Not at all—I consider he was quite capable of taking care of himself—a gentleman came with him in a cab to my house, and they had four pints of ale between them.
SARAH BLAKE. I am a monthly nurse—Mr. Soper sent me a message by a young man—the prisoner is the person—I have no doubt about him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did Soper afterwards come himself? A. Yes—he first came in a cab with a gentleman, and about a quarter of an hour after
wards he came again—he was the worse for liquor when he first came, he was not so bad the second time.

JOHN HERRINGTON. I am a furrier. On this Saturday night I heard a cry of "Stop thief!" and saw somebody running away—I could not swear to the person—I cannot say whether it was the prisoner or not—the person had on a cap a velveteen coat, and was about five feet four in height.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not say he was a stout man? A. No, I said he was neither stout nor thin—I did not see his face.

WILLIAM ROMAIN (policeman, L 38.) I took the prisoner into custody—he was in bed—I told him it was on suspicion of knocking a gentleman down, and robbing him on Saturday night, the 9th of Oct.—he denied the charge—he admitted that he was in company with a gentleman at the Corn-wall Arms, and that he had accompanied him into Princes-street, Stamford-street, but denied that he was the person that knocked him down.
Cross-examined. Q. What time did you take him? A. Between two and three in the morning, at his own lodging.

JOHN PRETTY
re-examined. The prisoner was dressed in a cap and vel
veteen coat when at my house.
(Elijah Harvey, floorcloth beater, Lambeth, and William Kay, stater, 6, Upper Marsh-street, Lambeth, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2492.
WILLIAM PIM,
HENRY CLARK,
JOSEPH EWINGTON , and
THOMAS ALLEN , were indicted for
burglariously breaking and enter
ing the dwelling-house of
John Pim, about twelve in the night of the 11th of Oct., at
Lambeth, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 1 coat, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, 2s.; 1 handkerchier, 1s.; and a variety of tools his property; 1 plough, 6d.; 3 saws, 5s.; and other tools, of
Thomas Seatle; Pim and Allen having been before convicted of felony; to which

PIM pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 24.—
Transported for Ten Years.

JOHN PIM. I am a builder, and live at 6, White Hart-place, Kennington-lane, in the parish of Lambeth—it is my dwelling-house—the prisoner Pim is my son—he worked for me, and lived in my house up to the 11th of Oct.—I went to bed that night about nine o'clock—I got up next morning about a quarter or ten minutes before six, came down stairs, opened my back-parlour shutters, and saw a ladder standing against the back stop—I then opened my front shop, and on returning to the back, saw my workman's tool-chest broken open—the lock had been cut away by some instrument—I do not know how

the house had been entered—some of my workman's best tools were gone from the chest, and a basket of my tools also, worth about 1l.—they were taken from the kitchen and workshop—I went to my son's bedroom, he was not there, and had not been in bed—I went into the front room first floor, found a cupboard broken open, and some spirits and wine gone—an attempt had been made to break open the door of my back-shop or iron-foundry, but that had not succeeded—I went into the kitchen, and there saw three chairs placed, and two empty bottles on the table—the thieves had been regaling themselves—here are a quantity of tools produced, some of which are mine, and some my workman's.

Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. Does the back shop adjoin the dwelling-house? A. There is about two yards' separation between my dwell
ing-house and the back shop—nobody lives in the back shop—there was no reason why my son should not have slept at home that night—I should say there were three persons engaged in this, from the three chairs which I found placed in the kitchen.

THOMAS SEATLE. I am assistant to Mr. Pin—I left my tools safe on Monday, the 11th of Oct., and missed them next morning—these now pro
duced are them—they are worth 1l. 17s. 10d.

THOMAS STEWART ROGERS (police-inspector L.) On Tuesday morning, the 12th of Oct., about a quarter to one, I was standing at Kennington-cross, about seventy yards from Mr. Pim's house, and saw a man cross from the direc
tion of Mr. Pim's, across Walcot-place, with a basket of tools on his back—I believe it was the prisoner Clark—he was staggering, I thought he was drunk.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know Clark? A. No—I believe him to be the person I saw, and pointed him out next day.

HENRY EVANS. I assist my father, who is a publican, at Lambeth. Last Monday week, about half-past twelve o'clock at night, Clark came to our house for half-a-pint of beer—I served him—he had a basket of tools over his arm, and a hand-saw in his hand—he asked if he might leave them till the morning—I said yes, and I put them in the kitchen—he was a little drunk—I gave the tools to the policeman in the morning.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean that he was a little intoxicated or very drunk? A. Very drunk—I did know him before, except by coming to the house once or twice.

THOMAS HENRY EVANS. I am last witness' father—I know Clark—I saw him in my skittle-ground on the Tuesday afternoon, about twelve o'clock—I asked what he wanted—she said a basket—I said what basket—he said a basket of tools that he had left the over-night with my eldest son—I said, "Tools!"—he said, "Carpenter's tools"—I said, "Indeed, then I want you," and I collared him, and gave him into custody—he said he was innocent, he knew nothing about it.

ABRAHAM ABRAHAMS. I am a broker, in Vere-street, Clare-market. On this Tuesday, about twelve o'clock, Pim, Ewington, and Allen came to my shop—Allen and Ewington had each a basket of tools—they asked if I would buy any tools—I said if I knew where they came from I would, if they would suit me—they directly walked to the back of shop into another room, and began to throw them out on the table—I said they would not suit me at any price, unless I knew where they came from—Allen said, "You may depend upon it they are all right, I have been known in this neighbourhood for a length of time, and I have pledged some of them in my name"—I did not like their proceedings, and said they would not suit me—they said I might have them for 1l., and then 10s. I told them to pack them up and go—they

were quite drunk, and were taking liberties with the servant girl—one of them whispered in my ear, "Give me a bob, you can have them for a bull"—I understood that to mean, that if I gave them 1s. I could have them for a crown—Phillips, the beadle, came in, and Allen immediately said, "Phillips knows me, you can buy them now with safety"—I would not—Phillips went away, and they packed the tools up—in going out of doors Ewington hit me in the face, and said I was a muff, and would not take a pound if it was given me—they took the tools away with them—these are the same sort of tools—this stock they pointed out to me as being worth a great deal. and also a brown great coat one of them had on—I believe it was Ewington—this is the coat.

JOHN PIM
re-examined. These are my tools, and these my man's—they are not the same I saw just now—this great coat is mine, and was in my house on the night in question.

JOHN PHILLIPS. I am street-keeper at St. Clement Danes. On the Tues
day in question went into Abrahams' shop, and saw Pim, Ewington, and Allen there, and a quantity of tools lying on the back-parlour table—Allen said, "Here is the beadle, he knows me well, why don't you buy them?"—I went out for a policeman—I afterwards took them in a cab to the station. and on the way Clark was brought up to the cab by another constable—they were taken in a public-house next door to Abrahams'—I produce the two baskets of tools, and the great coat which I found on Ewington's person, under his jacket I found this waistcoat, belonging to Mr. Pim, and this hand
kerchief in the coat-pocket.

Ewington's Defence. I was coming by Mr. Pim's about five o'clock on Tuesday morning, and met Mr. Pim's son, with a basket of tools, a great coat, and a waistcoat, which he asked me to help him carry; I did so; he told me to put the coat on, and said it was his own; I put it on, and he gave me the waistcoat to button underneath my own, which I did; I helped him carry the things to where he was going, and that is all I know about it.

Allen's Defence. I have worked in Covent-garden Market for four years; on Tuesday morning, at half-past eight, my wife brought me my breakfast, and about half-past nine I went into a public-house at the corner of Wild-street; Pim and Ewington were there drinking; I never saw them before; Pim offered me a pipe of tobacco; we got into conversation, and he said, "I have been on the spree all night, drinking wine and gin;" Ewington said the same; they said they had no money, and I stood a pint of porter; Pim pulled a saw out of a basket, and asked my wife to pawn it for 1s.; I said I would rather do it myself, and I went and pledged it; I forgot the name he told me, and gave my own and my address, No. 28, Portpool-lane, where I have lived two years and nine months; I gave Pim the ticket and money.
Pim. What Allen has stated is quite true; he is innocent.
JAMES GREEN. I produce a certificate of Allen's former conviction—(read—Convicted March, 1843, of housebreaking, and confined one year)—he is the person.
(Clark received a good character.)

CLARK—
GUILTY. Aged 31.

EWINGTON—
GUILTY. Aged 24.

ALLEN—
GUILTY.* Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2493.
JOHN MARSON was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining from
Henry Doulton 50 earthen pipes, by false pretences; 2nd COUNT, for con
spiring with others to obtain the said goods, with intent to defraud the said Henry Doulton and another of the same

HENRY DOULTON. I carry on business in partnership with John Doulton, in High-street, Lambeth. On the 24th of Aug., about three o'clock, in con
sequence of something I heard, I went to the Victoria-road, Kensington, and saw the prisoner there—I told him I understood he had called at our count
ing-house, and required a quantity of pipes for a sewer he was about to build in that neighbourhood—he said he did, he should want 600 of 9-inch pipes—I said, "I understand that the ground landlord of the property will be here, and will give me a guarantee for the payment"—he said he was there, and introduced me to a gentleman who he called Richard Day, Esq., of Eltham, who he said banked at Herries, Farquhar, and Co.—I and the prisoner walked on together, and left Mr. Day there—we went to Kensington new workhouse—it was not quite finished then—there was a sewer being made in the neigh
bourhood—the men were at work at it—he said, "You see that they are getting on with it, and if you don't send the first thing in the morning, they will be standing still"—he was almost within hearing of the men, I think they could have heard him, and he pointed to them—after that I went back to Mr. Day, and went to a public-house with him, and he gave me a guaran
tee for the payment, which I produce—it was given in the prisoner's presence—the next morning he sent a man, saying the works were standing still, and in consequence of what had passed the previous day, I sent fifty stone pipes, worth 5l. 12s. 6d.—a day or two after that, in consequence of something that my man told me, I went to look after the prisoner—he was not at home—he had left an address in my counting-house—I found the pipes were at Marl
borough-road, Chelsea, at the premises of Messrs. Humphrey and Thirak, on some premises that were building about a mile and a half from the sewer—I have never been paid—I made repeated applications, and wrote to Mr. Day, and he said when the order was completed, he would see that Mr. Marson paid it.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. You applied to Mr. Day more than once? A. I did—the prisoner gave his address Henry-street, Marlborough-road, Chelsea—I called there after the goods were sent, not before—I did not see him—I found that he lived there—it was a miserable house—a man that lived in such a house would not take such a contract—the guarantee was given in a public-house—the prisoner introduced me to Mr. Day as being the ground landlord—he had left word at my counting-house that the ground landlord would give me a guarantee—I should have parted with the pipes without the guarantee, under the circumstances, because when he said, in the presence of these men, he was building the sewer, I thought it sufficient guarantee to his respectability, that the guardians of the union should let out the work to him—I took the guarantee as an additional security—I did not require it—it was offered me, and I thought it right to accept it—I did not positively require it—I told him that I understood Mr. Day was willing to give it, and I was willing to receive it, and he gave it me—I did not mention it before I spoke of the price of the pipes—I had bargained about the pipes before he wrote the guarantee, but not I think before he mentioned that Mr. Day was willing to give it—I should, under the circumstances, have given the 70l. worth of pipes without receiving the guarantee, from the gentleman representing himself as the ground landlord—I really cannot say when I

applied to Mr. Day—it was a week or so afterwards—he said if I fulfilled the contract, he would comply with the guarantee—I did not see him—I never saw him after he gave me the guarantee—I saw the pipes about a week afterwards—I refused to send any more than the first load.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you find out that Mr. Day was a gentleman of fortune, living at Eltham? A. No, I did not go down to Eltham.

ROBERT STIMPSON. I am carman to Messrs. Doulton—I took these pipes to Victoria-road, near the new workhouse—I did not find the prisoner there when I first went—I found the sewer going on there; I then went back to the Victoria-road, and saw the prisoner—he said, "Where have you been to; you have been to the wrong place"—I said, "No, I have not; I have been to the sewer, near the New Union"—I told him, "I have heard you are not doing the sewer there, or at Victoria-road; Mr. Williams told me, that he did not know you, and he said he had the contract to do both sewers"—he said, "Mr. Williams dies not want to know me; for I took the job out of his hands"—I then left the pipes—I have not seen him since—I got him to sign on the bottom of my bill that he had received them—I communicated my suspicions to my master.

Cross-examined. Q. You had been to where these sewers were being made that day? A. Yes; I knew before I delivered the pipes, that he was not the contractor for those sewers—that was only from what I heard—I could not make it out, when he told me one story, and the other another.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. And not being able to make it out one way or the other, you did what your master told you? A. Yes.

ROBERT COCKBURN. I am a stone-mason, at 14, Marlborough-street, Chelsea. One Friday, at the latter end of Aug., the prisoner came to me, and asked me if I knew anybody that was likely to buy some stone pipes—I told him I did not know anybody more likely than Mr. Thirsk, as he was the only person I knew that used them—the prisoner asked me if I would go to Mr. Thirsk and ask him to buy the pipes—I said I would not, and told him to go himself—I afterwards removed them in a cart, from Kensing
ton to Messrs. Humphreys and Thirsk's—the prisoner employed me to do it—I saw him paid 4l. 19s. 6d. by Mr. Thirsk himself.

EDWARD THIRSK. I am a builder, and live at No. 11, Halsey-terrace, Cadogan-terrace, Chelsea—Cockburn brought the prisoner to me—the pri
soner asked me to buy fifty stone pipes for 5l.—I gave him 4l. 19s. 6d.—I could buy plenty at that price—it was a fair price.

SAMUEL WILLIAMS. I am a carman and building contractor, at 56, Clifton-street, Shepherd's-bush—I had the contract for building the new sewers, at Kensington New Union Workhouse, and nobody besides my brother and myself had any contract—it was for all the sewers that were to be made in the neighbourhood—I never gave the prisoner any authority at any time, to order any pipes for the sewers—I had no dispute with him about who was to have the contract—he never had anything to do with the contract—Mr. Gallott is the ground-landlord of the field where the pipes go across—Mr. Day, of Eltham, has nothing to do with it to my knowledge.

WILLIAM ATLEE (policeman.) I apprehended the prisoner—I told him I wanted him for obtaining some pipes from Mr. Doulton—he said, very well, he would go with me—I have been down to Eltham, in Kent, and have made inquiries for Mr. Day, a gentleman of fortune, living there—I found no gentleman of fortune living there of that name—there was a man named Day, lodging in a back-room at one Hennell's, a shoemaker's—I have been
searching for a Day and Hennell both since then, and have found neither—after I paid then the visit, they dissppeared—it was quite a small shop.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you go? A. I went on six or seven oc
casions—I have not seen Day at all—I found he had been living there—the first time I went was I think on the 9th of Oct.

GUILTY on 1st Count. Aged 38.—
Confined One Year. (See next case.)
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2494.
WILLIAM LEE was indicted
for unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, 480 lbs. weight of white of white lead, value 6l.; 12 gallons of varnish, 8l.; and other articles, the goods of
Augustus Ratcliffe, the younger; with intent to cheat and defraud him of the same.

AUGUSTUS RATCLIFFE, JUN. I am a window-glass and lead-merchant, in Chichester-place, Gray's-Inn-road. On the 7th of Aug. the prisoner came to my shop, and said he wanted to see Mr. Soar, my traveller—I said, "He is not in; shall I do as well"—he said he knew Mr. Soar from his calling on his former master, Mr. O. Donnel, who lived at Chelsea; that he had left him, through his doing some business for Mr. Richard Day, and had now started on his own account; that he had got some houses now to paint, I think he said five, and he wanted a lot of colour and turps to do them; would I supply them—he presented to me this bill (produced)—he left it with me—it is drawn by Marson upon Richard Day, Esq., of Eltham—I said I would take the bill, if he would let me take the particulars, and let me inquire at the Bank if it was all right—I took the particulars of the bill and made inquiries; and in consequence saw him again about the 12th—he then gave me the order, which was for a quantity of white lead and other things—this is the invoice (producing it), I took the bill—he said, "Be sure and send them over directly, because the workmen are standing still"—the bill is for 24l. 1s. 9d.
COURT. Q. It was the bill that induced you to send the things? A Yes—I parted with a little varnish afterwards on another pretence.

MR. PARNELL. Q. How long after did you see him again? A.
