About the 24th—he then brought a small phial containing some varnish—he said that was part of the first quantity I had sold him, that he had tried it on some clean white paper, and found it completely spoilt the whole of it—it was too dark for it, and would I let him have a lot more, much lighter—I let him have it—there was no invoice for that—he said be sure and send them directly, as his men were standing still—I sent part of it by the Parcels' Delivery Company for the men to go on with—the bill of exchange was more than covered by the first order—the second time I trusted to his representation of having a good job, and also that he wanted it in exchange for this other varnish—he represented that he had five or six houses to paint, and had five or six men on—the whole of the varnish was worth about 5l. 5s.—part was sent by the Parcels' Delivery Company, and part the Tasker—I have seen it since at Mr. Scott's, an oilman's, in the Marlboro'-road, Chelsea—the bill was returned to me—I have never been able to get the money—I went to where the prisoner lived—it was a small sort of chandler's-shop, at Chelsea—I have been down to Eltham to look for Mr. Day—there were two or three policeman after him then, I could not find him at all—I found the varnish at Mr. Scott's, on the 12th or 13th of October, the day after we look the prisoner into custody—the cans are here—(produced).

Prisoner. Q. When I presented that bill to you, did not I inquire for Mr. Soar? A. Yes—you did not tell me to go to the bank and see if it was correct—I said I would go—the varnish is not in the same invoice as the other things—eight gallons were sent afterwards.

EDWARD SCOTT. I live in Marlboro'-road, Chelsea. On the 13th of Aug., about the middle of the day, Marson, who was tried just now, came to me with a broker, named Smith, in the Fulham-road—in consequence of what Marson said, I saw the prisoner that same day in Turk's-row, Chelsea, where he was living—I purchased of him number of goods, some of which are here, and have been identified by the prosecutor—here are two cans which contained paper varnish, for which I paid the prisoner 30s.—he gave me a receipt for the money—I forget the date, I think it was after the 24th of Aug.—this is the receipt—it is dated the 1st of Sept., and is for 2l. 4s.—this includes some of the varnish—I had before that purchased oil and varnish of him to the amount of 7l. 15s.—I had not known him before.

JAMES TASKER. I am carman to the prosecutor—I delivered some varnish and brushes soon after the 24th of Aug., it might be four or five days after I delivered the first lot of goods, which was on the 13th of Aug.—I delivered them at Turk's-row, Chelsea—there were several persons there—when I first went I could not find the prisoner—once when I went, the prisoner said, had the varnish been there before, the rooms would have been varnished and dried, but he was not going to be humbugged by Mr. Ratcliffe, or anybody else, if he did not send it down, he must do something else with it, but did not say what.

JAMES MORRIS. I live in Turk's-row, Chelsea, opposite the prisoner. In the middle of Aug. I saw a great quantity of white lead and oil at the prisoner's—I was employed by him to roll it into the back yard—about a week afterwards, I saw some varnish brought there, and the prisoner employed me next day to take it to Mr. Scott's—I never saw the prisoner at work, he is a carpenter by trade, but I have seen him about Turk's-row all day long, backwards and forwards—I never saw any men employed by him, or say carts going from his premises—he has been living there nearly two years—he was at work seven or eight months ago, for a Mr. O'Donnell—I have not known him at work for anybody since—I am at work for a cowkeeper, and have been for the last nine years, on and off—my father is a pensioner.

CHARLES WALKER. I keep the house, 7, Turk's-row, Chelsea. The prisoner has lodged there upwards of two years—he did work for Mr. O'Donnell, and left him about three months ago—I do not think he has been in any employment since—I recollect the paint and varnish being brought to the house, it remained there two days—I saw the cart take it away the second evening—the prisoner hired the cart to take it to Mr. Scott's—none of it was sent to use at any house that I know of—the prisoner was not employed in painting or papering any houses at that time I know of—he was generally about the premises—I never saw any workmen come to him.

Prisoner's Defence. Marson brought this bill to me, and said he had taken one or two houses from Cockburn (who was a witness against him,) to paint, and asked me if I could get any credit—I said I did not know—he said, "Can you get anything on this bill?"—I said, "I do not understand anything about this bills"—he said, "If you can, I can get a bill, and a very good acceptance"—next day he brought me this bill—I took it to Walker, who said it was all right—I took it to Mr. Ratcliffe, and told him may busi
ness, that I had so and so to do, and had taken this bill, if he liked to take it in the way of ade—the thing was agreed on—I went with Marson to

Cockburn, and agreed to take 10l. to paint the house, and when I found that everything was not exactly correct I would not have any more to do with it—I was made a tool of altogether—Day I never saw, but Marson told me he was a man of independent property.

ROBERT COCKBURN. Marson brought the prisoner to me as a painter, and I agreed to give Marson 10l. for painting the house—the prisoner said he was a painter, and he was going to paint it and grain it likewise—I said I wanted to done directly, as I wanted to let it at Michaelmas.

CHARLES WALKER
re-examined. I know Marson by sight—I have seen him at my house several times with the prisoner—the prisoner said that he and Marson were going into partnership in business, and he showed me a bill in which both names were.

GUILTY.—
Confined Nine Months.

2494.
DAVID ABEL BROWN was indicted
for bigamy.

WILLIAM BROWN. I am pensioner in Greenwich Hospital, the prisoner is my son. I was present at his marriage to Maria Stokes, to the best of my knowledge in 1839—she is alive—I saw her just now outside the Court.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. How long did he live with her after her marriage? A. They have been separated so many times, I can hardly tell you—they have been separated four times I know, and he has taken her back again—she would go away with other men, and live with them, and leave her husband and child, a little boy about seven years old, behind her—he has forgiven her two are three times, and taken her back, and some short time afterwards she has left him again, and her way of life has been horrible to mention—she has behaved very badly indeed, no woman could behave worse—I did not know of the prisoner's marrying a second time—I know now he has been living some time with a second wife—he is a waterman and lighterman—I cannot find any fault in him, he is kind, ste and hard working.

ELIZABETH BRANDON QUENNELL. I was married to the prisoner on the 27th of July, 1846, and have been living with him ever since—I was single before that, and living with my mother, in Brandon-street—I had no money—I have had no child, and am not with child now.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you lived with him up to the time of this charge being made? A. Yes—I always found him good and kind—there might be as good a husband, but none better, he was a hare-working, Indus
trious man—I never knew him in liquor, and any time in the night, no matter what hour, he would get up to work and earn his living—it is not my inten
tion to abandon him now—I intend still to live with him.
JOHN BAKER (policeman) I produce copies of the two certificates of marriage—I compared them myself with the original, they are correct—(read).

Cross-examined. Q. Have you made inquiries about him in the neigh
bourhood? A. I have, and found him bear the character described—the character of his first wife is vary indifferent indeed.

GUILTY. Aged 30.—Strongly recommended to mercy.—
Confined Four Months

2495.
ROBERT WAITE was indicted for
stealing 4 1/4 lbs. weight of cheese, value 3s. 9d.; and 8lbs. weight of butter, 8s.; the property of
George Pickett, his master; and
ELIZABETH SYMMONDS and
EDWIN PICKERING
, for feloniously receiving the same; to which

WAITE pleaded
GUILTY.

GEORGE PICKETT. I am a cheesemonger, at High-street, Newington-butts. Waite was my shopman—I gave him in charge, and got an order from a Magistrate to search Symmonds' house—she at first denied having goods in the house—afterwards when the policeman said, "I shall look at see"—she said, "We have some that were delivered to me yesterday, and I have not paid for them, because I wash for Robert and do for him" (meaning Waite)—she brought down a great quantity of butter and cheese, and said something to her son—he ran into the yard with two books, which he put down the water
closet—the policeman got them out—these are them (produced)—there are entries in them to a very great amount, since the 14th of May, of the delivery of cheese and butter which I believe to be my property—they show the delivery of goods which Mrs. Pickering has received—she acknowledged they were mine—she said Robert had been in the habit of bringing goods to her house, and she had not paid him for them, because she did for him.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is that in your deposition? A. I do not recollect, I believe I stated it to the Magistrate—Waite was not allowed to sell for me on commission—it appears he has done so—a witness whose name I do not know represented that he was allowed to do so.

JANE ELIZABETH ORTIEB. The prisoner Waite called at my house one evening to solicit my custom, saying that Mr. Pickett would allow him a commission on any person who was a good customer—I have dealt with him in that way from that time—for the first three weeks a young man from Mr. Pickett's shop brought the things, and from that time I received them of Mrs. Symmonds.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he say that Mr. Pickett had given him permis
sion to sell on commission? A. Yes—the three first bills were Mr. Pickett's bills—he received about 4s. a week of me.
ELEANOR BOAKES. I have been in the habit of buying things weekly of Mrs. Symmonds—I understood that she had them for bad debts in business—I was introduced to her by an old window-lady.

WILLIAM COOMBS (policeman.) After Waite was in custody I went to the house, and asked Symmonds if she knew anything about the butter—she said, "Yes"—I said, "Do you know Robert Waite, he is in custody for robbing his master"—she said, "I have nothing in my house, and have had nothing of Mr. Pickett's"—I said, "I must search"—she said, "What I have had I have always paid for; there is some butter up stairs"—I found 8lbs. of butter, and 5 1/4lb. of cheese—I said, "Is that paid for?"—she said, "No; I wash and do for Robert, and I believe he has always accounted to Mr. Pickett"—while I was there Pickering ran out with two books, and attempted to put them into the water-butt.
JOHN CONSTABLE. I got the books out of the water-closet.
(Symmonds received a good character.)

SYMMONDS—
NOT GUILTY.

PICKERING—
NOT GUILTY.

2496.
ROBERT WAITE was again indicted for
stealing 5 1/4 lbs. weight of cheese, value 3s. 9d.; and 2 8/4lbs. weight of bacon, 2s. 3d.; the goods of
George Pickett, his master: and
ELIZABETH SYMMONDS and
ED
WARD PICKERING
, for feloniously receiving the same: to which

WAITE pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 30.—
Transported for Seven Years.

GEORGE PICKETT. I have lost some bacon and cheese, besides that charged in the other case, altogether about 120l. worth—I know that Mrs. Boakes received it of Mrs. Symmonds. WILLIAM COOMBS (policeman.) I went to Mrs. Symmonds, told her I came to search her house, said that Waite was in custody for robbing his master, and asked if she had any butter and cheese there—she said she had not—I said, "Do you mean to say you never had, for he has told all about it?"—she said, "I have, but I have always paid for it"—I said, "I must go over the house"—I did so, I found no bacon.

ELBANOR BOAKES. I bought some bacon of Mrs. Symmonds—she said she was obliged to take it for a bad debt when she was in business—I have had two hams—(produced)—I have had butter, cheese, and bacon—I cannot tell to what amount—it is in the book—it may be 15l.—I and she kept the book—she had things of me as well as I having things of her.

GEORGE PICKETT
re-examined. This butter is mine—Waite had the op
portunity of taking it—I charged him with robbing me, I did not say what of—he confessed it—I had not seen the bacon there—I have not spoken to him about it since—Symmonds frequently came to the shop in my absence.
(MR. CLARKSON contended that Symmonds was the thief, and not the receiver.)

SYMMONDS—
NOT GUILTY.

PICKERING—
NOT GUILTY.

2497.
CHARLOTTE CURLING was indicted for
stealing 1 ring, value 14s., the goods of
Thomas Hanibourne Bicknell, her master; and
MARY ANN LUCAS
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

CURLING pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

LUCAS pleaded
GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

2498.
HANNAH HOLLIS was indicted
for stealing 2 petticoats, value 5s.; 1 pair of shoes, 3s.; 1 pair of stockings, 1s.; 1 gown, 2s.; and 1 shift, 1s.; the goods of the
Guardians of the Poor of St. Saviour's, Southwark; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

2499.
ELIZABETH BROWN was indicted
for unlawfully uttering coun
terfeit coin.

SOPHIA GRANT. I am the wife of John Grant. On the 2nd of Oct. the prisoner came into my brother's shop, and asked for a quire of paper and a stick of sealing-wax—I served her—she gave me a sovereign—I gave her change, a half-sovereign and nine shillings—I asked her to give me a penny, and I would give her a sixpence—she said she had not one—she then said, "This half-sovereign don't sound a good one"—I said, "I am quite sure it is"—she said she did it to save trouble, not to bring it back again—I said, "Let me look at it"—I took it in my hand, put on my glasses, felt very doubtful of it, and called a boy and told him to go to Mr. Field, to see if it were good—thy boy went, and brought it back again, bent double—I got it back—I am quite sure it was not the half-sovereign I had given the prisoner—mine was a good one—I had been very particular in taking it—I

had taken it the day before, and I had not another—I gave the bent half
sovereign to my brother when he came home—he gave it to the policeman—I gave the prisoner the sovereign back.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You first thought you had taken your half-sovereign from a teacher that lived opposite? A. Yes, and then I found I did not, it was a mistake of my brother's—I said I was confused, and did not know what I was about, and the prisoner might as well have taken the nine shillings, but she did not take them—I had taken my half
sovereign of a person whose face was familiar to me, but not a teacher—I have been in the jewellery business some years and am a good judge of money, but I never heard of ringing the changes before—I took my half
sovereign out of my pocket—I had had it there one day.

CHARLES MILES. I am in the service of Mr. Cockin. On the 2nd of Oct., about five o'clock in the afternoon, Mrs. Grant gave me a half-sovereign to take to Mr. Field—I took it him—he gave it me back, and I took it to Mrs. Grant.
Cross-examined. Q. What did Mr. Field do with it? A. He bent it on the counter—he did not take it into another room.
GEORGE FIELD. The boy Miles gave me a half-sovereign—I gave him the same back.
GEORGE COFFIN. I got a half-sovereign from my sister, Sophia Grant—I gave it to George Beck, the constable.
GEORGE BECK (policeman, V 164.) I produce the half-sovereign.

MARTHA STANDNIG. My husband keeps a china-shop. On the 5th of Oct. the prisoner came and wanted a china mug, with the name of "Mary" or "Ann" on it—I looked and could not find one—she looked at the counter, and said, "I will take one of these custard-cups"—the price of it was 1s.—she gave me a sovereign—I had no change, and went up to my cash-box, and brought down nine shillings and a half-sovereign—I did not think it was right, and I bit the sovereign before I took it up stairs, and sounded it before her—she said, "It is a good one"—I gave her the change—she was putting it away, I turned to put the custard-glass into a piece of paper, and she said, "This half-sovereign does not sound well; I think it is cracked"—I said, "Let me see it"—she hesitated for a moment, and I asked her again—she gave it me, and said, "It is a cracked one"—I took it from her hand, and said, "It is a very base one"—I bit it double, and said, "I am confident this is not the one I gave you"—she said directly, "Oh, my good soul, what could I have done with the other!"—I said, "I don't know; I am confident this is not the one I gave you," and directly she faltered, and said, "If you will give it me, let me see it; I will take it to my father, and he shall see it, or I will cut it in two before him"—I did not allow her to go—she said, rather than there should be a bother she would leave the shop.

WILLIAM COTTON (policeman, F 52.) I took the prisoner—this half
sovereign was given me by Mrs. Stevens.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not the prisoner say she had no other half
sovereign, it was the same the lady gave her? A. Yes—this was marked before it was given me.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These half-sovereigns are both counterfeit, and both cast in one mould—they have been cast first in white metal and then galvanized.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

2500.
ALFRED DAWSON was indicted
for a like offence.

WILLIAM DAVIES. I keep the Queen's Head, at Mortlake. On the 22nd of Sept. I served the prisoner some brandy—he tendered me a half-crown in payment—I bit it, and found it was bad—it was put into the fire by the pri
soner's request—he went away, and I followed him, and saw him in Mr. Willis's shop.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You said you believed it to be Alfred Dawson? A. Yes—he was much surprised when I told him the half-crown was bad—he gave me shillings, and said he was sorry such a thing should happen, and was not aware he had it about him—he did not stay more than five minutes at my house—he staid till the half-crown was melted—I showed him the pieces.
MR. WILDE. Q. Were you sent for by Mr. Day? A. Yes—I saw the prisoner, and said he was the same person.

WILLIAM LANGRIDGE. I keep a beer-shop. On the 22nd of Sept. the prisoner came for a glass of ale—he gave me a half-crown—I returned him 2s. 4d. out—he went away—I examined the half-crown in about five minutes afterwards—I am quite certain it was the same I received from him—it was bad, and I threw it on the fire—there was no fire alight—I took it out and gave it to Dumain.

Cross-examined. Q. How long did the prisoner stay at your house? A. Five or six minutes—nothing passed between him and me about the half
crown—he had a glass of old ale—my suspicion was not at all excited by the half-crown—I took it and put it away—in consequence of something I heard afterwards I went and looked at it—I am a pork-butcher and a beer-shop keeper—I am in the habit of taking a good deal of silver.

GEORGE DAY. I keep the public-house at Mortlake. On Wednesday, the 22nd of Sept., I saw the prisoner served with some brandy by Elisabeth Day, my niece—he put her down a half-crown to pay for it—I thought it was good—I bit it, and found it was bad—he wanted me to give it him back—he said, "Let me look at it"—I said I would take care of that and him too—I sent for Mr. Davies—he said the prisoner was the same person who had been offering him a half-crown.

Cross-examined. Q. Did the prisoner bear Mr. Davies say so? A. He was quite close to him—he wanted to go to his friends—he was in my place half an hour altogether, being searched and all—after I told him it was bad he said, "Give it to me, or throw it away"—he said he did not know he had such a thing about him—he had 6d. worth of brandy and water after
wards—if I had not heard something about it I should have taken the half
crown as good—when the second brandy was supplied him he seemed a little fidgetty—he drank about one-third of it.
MR. HORRY. Q. Did he appear drunk? A. He appeared very sober when he came in, and afterwards seemed to be very fidgety—he said he should lose the train and omnibus—he was very anxious to get away.
JAMES DOMAN (policeman, V 120.) On Wednesday, the 22nd of Sept., I received from Mr. Davies these pieces of melted metal, and one half-crown from Mr. Langridge, and this other from Mr. Day.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL. These pieces of white metal are the same as these two half-crowns—they are both counterfeit, but of different reigns.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

2501.
JAMES LEE was indicted
for stealing 45lb. weight of lead pipe, value 11s.; 1 basket, 10d.; the goods of
George Robinson, his master.

GEORGE DAY. I am foreman to Mr. George Robinson—the prisoner was in his employ. I was at work on the 4th of Oct. at Richmond, and about four o'clock in the afternoon I saw the prisoner coming out of a shed where there was lead kept—he was bringing part of a coil of lead—he placed it at the end of the shed, near a wall, where there was a path on the other side—he went back to the shed—he had no business whatever with the lead—it was my master's—he moved it about twenty yards.

THOMAS PIRIES. I went into the shed on that day and saw the prisoner bending a piece of lead backwards and forwards—I told the foreman and went back to my work—in half an hour afterwards I saw the prisoner take a roll of lead and put it behind a place on my master's premises—I am certain it is my master's lead.
GEORGE WOODS (policeman, V 209.) I took the prisoner and have the lead—I found this basket at the prisoner's lodging.

GEORGE DAY
re-examined. This basket is my master's property.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

2502.
ALEXANDER STORAR was indicted
for stealing 1 barometer, value 10s., the property of
Robert Bastow and others.
BENJAMIN WILLMOT WHEATLAND. I am an officer of the Southwark Literary Institution. On the 18th of Sept. I missed a barometer—this is it—it is the property of Robert Bastow and others.
JAMES WALTER. I am a pawnbroker—I have a barometer I took in—I cannot say of whom—this is the duplicate I gave of it.
RICHARD MERRONY (policeman, R 102.) I took the prisoner—I found this duplicate on him of the barometer pawned on the 18th of Sept.

Prisoner's Defence. A man named Hardy owed me some money; I asked him several times for it, and he told me to call on Saturday afternoon, and he would give me part and security for the rest; I called, he gave me a shilling, and said he had a barometer out of repair, I might pawn it; I did so; I sent my wife to the man afterwards, and he was gone away—I told the officer where I lived and where I worked.

RICHARD MERRONY
re-examined. Yes, he did—I went to his masters, who said he knew nothing dishonest of him.

GUILTY. Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

2503.
SARAH GROOM was indicted
for stealing 1 shawl, value 2s., the property of
Phoebe Pearce; having been before convicted of felony.

PHOEBE PEARCE. I am single, and live at Mortlake. On the 18th of Oct. I saw the prisoner at Richmond with my shawl on—I had seen it safe at home at four o'clock that afternoon—I went home, it was gone from the table where I had left it—I went back after the prisoner and gave her in charge—the policeman took the shawl from her—this is my shawl.
SOPHIA PEARCE. I know this shawl—it belongs to Phoebe Pearce.
JAMES STRUDWICK (policeman, V 205.) I found the prisoner lying in a privy with this shawl.

JOHN CANNON (police-sergeant, V 6.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction—(read—Convicted Sept., 1845, and confined four
teen day solitary)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.

2504.
WILLIAM THOMPSON and
GEORGE RAINBOW were in
dicted for
stealing 2lbs. weight of tea, value 10s.; 1 handkerchief, 1s.; the goods of
Henry Peter Helwig, Thompson having been before convicted; to which

THOMPSON pleaded
GUILTY.* Aged 16.

RAINBOW pleaded
GUILTY.* Aged 15.

2505.
MARY ANN PALMER was indicted
for stealing 2 sheets, value 4s.; 2 frocks, 4s.; 1 spencer, 2s.; the property of
William Bromley, her mas
ter; also one gown, value 7s., the property of
Henry Joseph King; to which she pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

2506.
MARY MASON,
WILLIAM BROWN , and
ELIZA WEAVER , were indicted for
stealing 45 yards of lace, value 3l. 9s., the property of
Wil
liam Kingston; Mason having been before convicted of felony.

RICHARD JOLLIFFE LANGDON. I am shopman to William Kingston, of West
minster-bridge-road—on Wednesday, the 22nd of Sept., at half-past three in the afternoon, the prisoner Mason and another woman came to the shop and asked to look at some black edgings—I showed them some of different widths—there was some lace in the same box—I took out several cards of lace and edging, and laid them on the counter—Mason and the other woman looked at them—Mason asked for a yard and quarter of black edging—it was 8 1/2d. a yard—I served her—I then went and got some other goods to show them—I was away a very short time—long enough for a person to go out of the shop and return without my observing it—I then sold something to the other woman—the officer came in and told the foreman not to let the women go—I think Mason heard it—the foreman then spoke to me—I looked at the goods at the door—I did not miss anything—in a quarter of an hour afterwards Laylan and I went to the station—I there saw three cards, con
taining 48 yards of lace, worth about 3l. 9s.—I knew them to be my master's property—I had had it out while Mason and the other woman were there—this is it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Has your master any partner? A. No—the two women bought separate things—they came in at the same time, and went out the same time—I did not miss anything—I did not see one of them go out—I know this from the marks on it—it was on the counter while they were in the shop—I took it out of the box—I looked at the goods at the door, as the foreman understood it was from there, and did not miss anything—I did not search amongst the property on the counter—there were perhaps twenty or thirty cards of lace in the box—I know this was not sold, we never sell it so—if these had been sold, we should probably have put them on one card.
Cross-examined by MR. PARTINGER. Q. You only speak to two women being in the shop? A. No.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Were these cards of lace part of what you had in the box? A. Yes, I have no doubt they were—I had a quantity of this sort and width—while I was gone to the station our people found we had lost lace of this description—I have not looked in the box myself to see whether any of this was gone—we cut lace in lengths—we sell it with our

private marks on the cards—nobody but me served the women with lace—I did not serve them with this—I produced such lace as this while they were there, but did not serve any of this to Mason or the other woman—neither of them bought this.

JONATHAN WILLCHER. (police-sergeant, 27 A.) On Wednesday afternoon, the 22nd of Sept., I saw the prisoners and another woman in Westminster-road—Mason and the other woman went into Mr. Harvey's shop—they left there, and went to Mr. Kingston's—Mason and the other woman went in—the other prisoners remained outside, near the shop-door—I saw Mason or the other woman, I am not certain which, but I believe Mason, come out and go to Weaver, and, as it appeared to me, give her something, which Weaver put under her shawl—the woman then returned to the shop directly, and Weaver and Brown went down Phœnix-street, which adjoins Mr. Kingston's shop—I told Langley what I had seen, went into the shop, and saw Mason and the other woman sitting at the counter—I told the foreman I was an officer, and I gave him instructions to retain the women, which it seems they did not attend to—I then came out and joined Langdon—we went down Phœnix-street, and about 200 yards down, Brown and Weaver were standing talking—I said to Weaver, "What have you got under your shawl?"—she said, "Nothing"—I lifted up her shawl, and found three cards of lace under her arm—I said, "What do you call these?"—she said she picked them up in the street—I took hold of Brown, and said he must go to the station—Langley took hold of Weaver—I had seen the prisoners together about twenty minutes before they went to the shop—they were all walking together—at the time Mason or the other woman brought something out, and gave to Weaver, Brown was close by, within two or three yards of the window—it is a corner house—he might be half a dozen yards from the door—I found on Weaver a purse, nine shillings, and a penny, four or five pieces or ribbon, two small bits of lace, and pair of child's socks, all new—I went with Langley about three hours afterwards to the Swan public-house in Bishops
gate-street, saw Mason there, and told her I apprehended her for taking some lace that afternoon in Westminster-road—she said I was mistaken, she had not been in Westminster-road, nor on that side the water—I am certain she is the person—I know her well—there was a new scarf found on Brown—this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. PARTINGER. Q. When you took Brown, he said he knew nothing of the robbery? A. Yes; he said before the Magistrate that he accidentally met Weaver.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Where were you standing? A. passed them first on the same side of the way—I then went over the way to watch them—there is a pawnbroker's shop at the opposite corner to Mr. Kingston's—Brown and the woman not in custody live as man and wife.

EDWARD LANGLEY (police-serjeant, A 25.) I was with Whicher, in Westminster-road, on Wednesday the 22nd of Sept., and I saw the three prisoners and another—I watched them down the Westminster-road, from Mr. Harvey's shop to Mr. Kingston's, which is more than 100 yards—I saw Brown and Weaver remain outside, Mason and the other woman went into Mr. Kingston's shop, and remained some time—Brown and Weaver remained outside—they then went down the street—Whitaker and I went down, and asked Weaver what she had under her shawl—she said, "Nothing"—we lifted her shawl, and took from under her right arm the three cards of lace—I searched Brown, and found on him this scarf, a small knife, and this dupli
cate
of a ring—I afterwards went to the public-house and took Mason—she was told what she was taken for—she said she had never been on that side the water.

THOMAS GRUBEY. I am apprentice to Mr. Kingston. I was in the shop when the two women came in for some lace—Langdon served them—while he was away I saw one of the women, who I believe was Mason, leave the shop and came back.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was it not the shorter one of the two whom you believed was Mason? A. Yes—she is shorter than the other was.
HENRY MERVYN (policeman, F 139.) I produce a certificate of Mason's former conviction, by the name of Mary Rode—(Read—Convicted Aug. 1845, confined four months)—she is the person.
(Brown and Weaver received good characters.)

MASON—
GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

BROWN—
GUILTY. Aged 34.—
Confined Nine Months.

WEAVER—
GUILTY. Aged 27.—
Confined Nine Months.

2507.
THOMAS BURKETT,
PATRICK GAINOR,
DAVID RAY
MOND , and
JACOB HERRINGTON , were indicted for
stealing 30 pence and 60 halfpence, the moneys of
Samuel Bromley; Burkett having been before convicted of felony; to which
GAINOR. Aged 14.
RAYMOND. Aged 14.

pleaded
GUILTY.—
Confined Three Months and
Whipped.

SAMUEL BROMLEY. I am a cheesemonger. On the 11th of Oct. I left my horse and cart at Lambeth, in charge of the prisoner Burkett—I went to a shop, came back, looked into my cart, and found 10s. of copper was gone—a youth gave me 5s. of it—he said he went after them, and they bit his hand—when Burkett came back, Smith accused him of it—he said it was a lie.

JOHN SMITH. I am in the employ of Mr. Wright. On the 10th of Oct. I saw Burkett standing at the horse's head—he beckoned to Raymond, and showed him something that was in the riding-box of the cart—Raymond went away and beckoned, and then Gainor came and stopped with them five mi
nutes—then Raymond and Harrington came up—Gainor got on the step of the cart, and got two 5s. papers of copper—he gave them to Harrington—I went after Harrington and got one paper back—the others went away.
FRANK TURNER (policeman, L 114.) I produce a certificate of Burkett's former conviction—(read—Convicted May, 1847, confined three months and whipped.

BURKETT—
GUILTY. Aged 16.—
Confined One Year and
Whipped.

2508.
HENRY EDWARD MATTHEWS was indicted
for stealing 1 shilling, 4 pence, and 1 halfpenny; also 3 shillings, the moneys of
Robert Richardson Hannah, his master; to both of which he pleaded

GUILTY. Aged 15.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Four Months

2509.
ELIZABETH CORNWALL was indicted
for stealing 12 sove
reigns, the moneys of
Maria Bromley.

MARIA BROMLEY. I live in Frederick-place, Old Kent-road. The prisoner was occasionally staying with me—on the 13th of Aug. I put twelve sove
reigns

into my chest—I have not seen them since—the prisoner was there on the 14th—I missed them two or three weeks afterwards—the chest was locked, but the prisoner frequently borrowed my keys—no one else borrowed them—the prisoner borrowed 5s. of me—she said she had no money, and very few clothes—I said she must go and seek a situation.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. She had a box there? A. Yes—I do not know that one of my keys opened it—her key was at the bottom of a large box—she borrowed my friend's keys as well as mine—she said they would not do, and borrowed mine the same day, and several times afterwards—I know she was there on the 14th, because I had a friend there that day—she said if I would go with her to Islington I should he paid back all the money I had lost—I have had no quarrel with her—I keep a bonnet-stop—this money I brought with me to pay a baker's bill.
ELLEN FRENCH. The prisoner came to me in July, and with me up to the 13th of Sept.—I was she had six or seven sovereigns and some silver.

Cross-examined. Q. How was this money shown to you? A. I was standing at the corner of the table, and she took her purse, and paid me for an article I purchased for her—she did not appear timid in showing the gold.

ANN FITZGLIN. The prisoner came to live with me in Little Qucen-street—the policeman came there look in the drawers—the prisoner pointed with her finger—I could not understand what she meant—she then said to me, "Say it is yours"—the officer was then looking at a brown paper parcel—I had seen the prisoner with some silver the night before, but no gold.

Cross-examined. Q. Did the policeman hear what she said? A. Yes—he said to me, "Is this yours?"—I hesitated about it, and then said, "Yes"—he said, "Are you sure?"—I then said, "No"—I was rather confused—she appeared quite calm, and spoke to the officer as if he were a friend.

WILLIAM MORTEN (police-sergeant, T 7.) I took prisoner—I charged her with stealing 12l.—she said, "I stole no money"—I asked for her pocket—she gave me this purse, which contained some silver—I said, "You had some money"—she said, "Who said so?"—I said, "Mrs. French"—she then said she had 10l. given her by a gentleman she had lived with, and there was a letter in her box would show it—I then searched a drawer and found a parcel—I saw her make a sign to Miss Fitzglin—I found a dress and a number of other things in the parcel, all new—I told her I un
derstood she bought those things after leaving Mr. Bromley's—she said, yes, but most of them were presents—I took her to the station—she said, "I have not stolen Mrs. Bromley's money, but if you will go to Islington the money will be paid."

2510.
WILLIAM JAMES HOPKINS was indicted
for stealing 40 bushels of oats, value 5l.; the goods of
John Dudin; in a barge on the Thames.

JOHN ADCOCK. I live in St. John-street, Horseleydown, and am a City deputy corn-meter. On the 4th of Oct. I went on board the barge Tennant, which was lying in the river, at Prince's-stairs, Rotherhithe—I went to do 330 quarters of oats—I delivered 260 quarters in the first barge—I saw the prisoner in the barge, acting as lighterman, in taking the oats in and stacking them—they were delivered partly in bulk and partly in sacks—I was called away from the hold after the 260 quarters had been delivered—on earning on deck I saw a skiff under the bow of the vessel; I noticed seven or eight sacks in the skiff. I saw the prisoner coming towards the moon hatch-way—that

was some distance from the skiff—I said to him, "You did not tell me you were going to take any oats in the skiff—he said, "Yes; five quar
ters"—I said, "It is strange you did not tell me"—he said, "It is all right"—I saw Wheeler standing at the stern of the barge—I said, it was strange that he did not tell me that he was loading the skiff—I asked Hopkins whether Wheeler worked for Mr. Dudin—he said, "Yes"—I had seen Hop
kins go to him and speak to him—I saw Wheeler take the skiff and tow it towards Prince's-stairs, with the sacks in it—I made out a bill and gave it to the prisoner—he said, "You have not given me a bill for the five quarters"—I said, "No"—he said, "Don't take any notice of the five quarters, as we have slinked them"—I went and gave information to Mr. Dudin.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. The prisoner was in Mr. Dudin's employ? A. Yes; as a lighterman—Mr. Dudin is a carman and lighter
man—he does not deal in corn—I know Wheeler by sight—I did not know that he was in Mr. Dudin's employ—it is usual to produce a written order for the delivery of corn; it would have been in the usual course for Wheeler to have brought a delivery order to me—he brought that order; but this was done while I was in the hold of the vessel—I saw the skiff when I was called up—the captain had charge of the Tennant—he would be the person to re
ceive the delivery order—he is not here—he was on board at the time this was going on—I cannot tell the meaning of the word slinked—the expre
sion was, "You have not given me a bill for the five quarters, "I said, "No;" and he said, "Take no notice of them, as we have slinked them"—I will swear he said that—I did not take any steps to stop the barge from going off—I did not deliver a bill for the five quarters.

COURT Q. Did the bill you delivered include the five quarters? A. Yes—I delivered the oats from the vessel into the barge—I was the man to measure them, and a lighterman was taking them into the barge—being called from below, I discovered a part of what was entered for the barge had got into the skiff—if they had been put into the barge it would have been all right—they had no business in the skiff as far as I know—Wheeler went away alone with the skiff—I do not know what became of it—the prisoner stopped—I loaded another barge with seventy quarters—a lad came and took me out by a note—the note was left on board the vessel—I acted upon that—an order was left for 200, and one for 130—two sacks contain a quarter—I had not delivered the 330 quarters when this conversation took place—I had delivered seventy—the skiff went away about twelve o'clock—the conversation about not noticing the five quarters must have been about half-past eleven—I had been in the interim delivering the rest—I do not count the sacks—the bulk here was 1600 or 1700 quarters—I take my shovel, and put it into the sacks, and score with chalk on the shovel—the employ sacks are thrown down, filled, and taken away—I am responsible for the quantity, because I deliver the quantity according to the order.

JAMES ASTED. I am a fellowship-porter, and was employed in delivering the oats—I saw the skiff with several sacks in it—my attention was called to it by the captain, and I saw Wheeler walk across the plank, across the barge we were loading, and put a sack into the skiff—I called Adcock—he said to the prisoner, "Why did you not tell me you were going to load a skiff?"—he said, "It is all right"—Adcock said, "Won't you want a bill for it?"—he said, "No, you can give me that when you have loaded the barge"—I thought that Wheeler was in Mr. Dudin's service as well as the prisoner—they had been working in the Eclipse barge that we were loading, and
brought a bundles of empty sacks—a boy who had been in the skiff three or four hours was sent on shore.

JOAN DUDIN. I am a master lighterman, and live in Gainsford-street, Horseleydown. On the 4th of Oct. the prisoner was in my service—Wheeler was not—I had 330 quarter of oats to work out of the Tennant on the day in question—I directed the prisoner to load the Eclipse, and to put the rest in the Jolon barge—I gave no direction as to the use of a skiff—the bundle of sacks was to stack the Eclipse—he was to take the Eclipse to Whiting's wharf—that was not done—Adcock gave me information—I after
wards saw the barge inside the tier—I found the skiff at Prince's stairs—nothing was in it then—it was in my charge, so that the prisoner could get it before twelve o'clock—I crossed the water—I saw a boy who I employed to load the barge, go ashore—the oats were to be delivered to Edward Raper—they were delivered, but not the five quarters—I have been charged for this defi
ciency, and had to pay for it—I went to the Thames-police-office, and went with an officer to find the prisoner—I found him in the George public-house—I asked him what had become of the five quarters—he said he knew no
thing about them.

Cross-examined. Q. Where was the Tennant lying? A. At Prince's stairs—about half a mile from Whiting's—I only employed the prisoner to unload this corn—there was a boy employed to turn the meter—the prisoner had not been long in my employ—he was merely employed by the day—that is the general practice—Wheeler is occasionally employed by persons there—that is the way he gets his living—I gave the order the night before—I have never recorded the five quarters, nor found what was done with them, nor found Wheeler.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 22.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

2511.
SAMUEL TOOMBS was indicted
for bigamy.

JOHN STRIDE. I am an engineer, and live in Victory-street, New Town, Deptford. I have know the prisoner about nine years—I was with him in Oct., about nine years ago, at the parish Church of St. George's, Bloomsbury, when he was married to Mary Woolridge—he was then about thirty or thirty-one years of age—I was one of the witnesses to the marriage—I after
wards saw them living together as man and wife for three or four years—she is now alive—I saw her five minutes ago—she is about the same age or rather older than the prisoner—I had not been there before the marriage—none of the other witnesses are here—my wife was one—I had known the female rather longer then the prisoner—the prisoner was a carpenter—I do not know the name of the elergyman who performed the ceremony—Mr. Catty was the clerk—he was present.

Cross-examined by MR. WOLLETT. Q. Do you know on what terms the prisoner lived with his wife? A. In my opinion he lived on very good terms—I do not knew of any separation—I have heard that it is three or four years ago since he left her—I then saw them living together very happily, and comfortably—there did not appear much disparity in their ages—I have heard of the prisoners allowing her so much a week.

JAMES POOR. I am a cabinet-marker, in Fulham-road, Hammersmith—I know the prisoner, and was him at St. Luke's Church, Chelsea, on last August twelvemonth, when he was married to Martha Ginger—she is not

here—I believe this prosecution is at the instance of the first wife—Martha Ginger was a single woman, about twenty-eight years old—she had no pro
perty—she was a servant.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the prisoner? A. Yes, personally—I do not know on what terms he lived with his wife—I have not heard of any separation—I never knew the wife—I have heard that he allowed her something weekly, up to recently.

WILLAM GIBBS (policeman, V 77.) The prisoner was given into my custody by his first wife—he told me he was very sorry, but he would go quietly with me—I have copies of the registers of the marriages—the first wife gave me this one—I examined it with the register at Bloomsbury Church, with the clerk—it is a true copy—and the other also—(read).
Cross-examined. Q. Did he say on what terms he lived with his first wife? A. No—I believe he allowed her 7s. 6d. a week till within the last month.

GUILTY. Aged 31.—
Confined One Year.

2512.
ANN RUGG was indicted
for stealing 2 sheets, value 4s., the property of the
Guardians of the Poor of St. Mary, Rotherhithe, to which she pleaded

GUILTY.—
Confined Two Months.

2513.
WILLIAM BASHFORD was indicted for
stealing 1 tarpaulin, value 4l., the property of the
South Eastern Railway Company; and
WIL
LIAM WEALFARE
, for feloniously receiving the same well knowing it to have been stolen.

JOHN HODSON. I am in the service of Thomas Edgington, of the Old Kent-road, a tarpaulin-manufacture—it is my duty to see to the outting out of articles made there, and delivering them to the Carmen—the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway Company are customers of my master—previous to the 6th of Sept. I cut out thirty tarpaulins for them—I saw twenty put in the cart, Nos. from 399 to 418—I saw the carman leave the premises with them for the railway at New Cross—I saw the tarpaulin No. 404—that was one of the twenty I saw on the van on the 6th of Sept.—the carman was John Briggs.
JOHN BRIGGS. I took the cart on the 6th of Sept. with the tarpaulins to the New Cross station—they were the same that Hudson put on the cart.

GEORGE RADCLIFF. I am clerk at the New Cross station of the railway—on the 6th of Sept. Briggs brought twenty tarpaulins to the office—they were all correctly delivered that day—they were worth from 2l. and 2l. 10s. each.

WILLIAM DOUGHTON. I live in York-street, Westminster—I know Bash
ford—I met him three weeks before the 9th of Oct., in Moorgate-street—he had his van with him—I was out of employ at that time—he asked me to go with him to the New Cross station—I went with him—the van stopped at the Sawn in the Dover-road—Bashford asked me to give him a sheet off the van—I said, "I don't see one"—he said, "Put the tilt back and you will see one"—I did, and I saw a sheet and gave it to him, and he took it into the Swan-yard—I let sheet down from the van, and Barkford held a sack and put it—I did not go down the yard with him—he came back in about

five minutes without the sack—there was a pot of beer to drink, I had some of it—we went in the van to New Cross station—on the road I asked what that was he had taken—he said it was one of the Company's sheets—I said I should not have liked to have had anything to have done with it—he said we should have a new pair of boots for the winter—the van was unloaded at the station and came back—I left it against the Bricklayer's Arms station—I saw Bashford some time after at the George Tap, in Aldermanbury—I asked him he had sold the sheet—he said "No"—I asked him if he was going to sell it—he said "Yes"—I said, what might the price be—he said, "a sovereign'—I said I knew a party who would have it, meaning Packman, the office—I saw Bashford again the next morning in the George Yard—he asked if I had seen that party—I said "No"—I afterwards saw Packman at the station, and told him what had taken place—he and I then went to the Swan Inn-yard, in the Dover-road—I went in the yard—I first saw Wealfare there, and I said, "We are come for that sheet"—he said, "Here it is, where is money"—I said, "I have not got the money. a man outside has it"—he said I had better get the money—I went to Packman, who gave me a marked sovereign, and we went to the stable together—I pointed Packman out and said, "This is the man who is going to have it"—I took the sack which had the tarpaulin in—they helped it on my shoulder—I cannot say whether it was the same tarpaulin—I brought it out and pitched it against the door—I gave Wealfare the sovereign which I had received from Packman.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You seem to have behaved very honestly in this matter? A. I do not know—I know the difference between being honest and being a thief—I did not know I was helping a thief—I did not get the new pair of boots—that was not the reason I informed—I have been in the habit of living in the George-yard some months, and there were three sets of harness stolen from there—I did not get share of the harness, I never saw it—I never saw what it fetched—I informed against the prisoners about the tarpaulin—I knew in whose service Bashford was—I thought the tarpaulin I saw come out of the cart was his master's—he held the bag, and I dropped it in—I thought he was going to put it on the van again—it is a customary thing to put them in sacks—I have never done it before—after it got in the yard I began to suspect, and I asked who it belonged to, and he said to the Company—I had no reason to disbelieve it—I did not think it ne
cessary to give information then—there was nothing said about my having a pair of boots of shoes—I supposed the parties who were to get the tarpaulin were to have them—I did not expect to get anything—I went to the railway and assisted to unload—I did not tell any one that one of the tarpaulins was gone—I cannot tell why I did not, I have not through about it—it was about a fortnight or three weeks after that I met with Packman—I had seen him coming into the about the case of the harness—I had nothing to do with that, only it was in the yard where I had been in the habit of working—it was not in my stable—Packman did not accuse me of stealing it—I heard that he mentioned it—it is not a bargain, that if I gave evidence against the prisoner, they will not proceed against me for the harness—the harness was in the same yard as the tarpaulin—I have been in the habit of being in the yard for several months.

MR. HUDDLFSTON. Q. Do you know anything about this harness? A. No—other persons were in the yard where it was lost from—it is a public yard—I heard that I and others were suspected—Packman came there about it—he never charged me with stealing it—there was a mention of the harness,
and it got an old master of mine that I lived with there years, and he spoke to me about it, thinking I was taken up for it, and that was the reason I gave this account.

WILLIAM GREGGS. I live in Long-alley, Finsbury, and am a hatter—some weeks before the 9th of Oct. I saw a van at the Swan, in the Dover-road—Bashford was the driver, and there was a little boy on it—I saw Doughton riding on the box with Bashford—Bashford asked Doughton to gave him a sheet from the top of the van, under the tarpaulin, and Doughton let it down from the top into a sack—Bashford took it up the yard by the said of the public-house—I saw him come back without it—on the 7th of Oct. I was at the George-tap, Aldermanbury—I saw Bashford conme in, and Doughton asked him if he had got rid of the sheet—he said no, he should like to do so—Doughton said he thought he could get him a customer—a sovereign was mentioned as the price of it.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. I am not at present in any situation—I had two days' work last week in George-street, Blackfriar-road—Doughton formerly lived with Mr. Sweeting, in Cheapside—he drove his cart—I was not in the habit of driving in his cart—I have a brother who lives up the George-yard. and it was him who lost the harness—I never heard that Doughton was accused of having stolen it—I go to the George-yard perhaps on an evening—I had seen the harness—I dare say I might have seen it in company with Doughton—I frequently go in the stable—I only have Bashford by seeing him once or twice—when I saw Douhgton hand this tarpaulin to Bashford, I made no remark—I did not know but he might be obliged to leave it there—hearing that Doughton was seen with the policeman, I mentioned the tarpaulin to my brother—we were merely talking about the circumstance, and I happened to say that I saw it, and my brother brought me up to the policeman.

ROBEART PARKMAN (City policeman 133.) On the 9th of Oct., I received in
formation from Doughton. I went to the Swan, in the Dover-road—I gave Doughton a marked sovereign—I followed him to the stable, and saw Wealfare—he was bringing a sack from one of the stalls in the stables—he looked at me, and said, "You have got a good bargain'—I said, "Is it full size?"—he said, "Yes, it is fifteen feet long"—the sack was them put on Doughton's shoulder, and taken out—I asked Wealfare what he sold it for—he said, "1l."—I said, "Was it your property?"—He said, "No"—I said, "How do you account for the possession of it?"—he said, "I know nothing of it, I was only told to sell it"—I said I was an officer, and asked him to be so kind as to hand me the sovereign—he put his pocket, and gave me the marked sovereign out.

Cross-examined. Q. When had you known Doughton before? A. About three weeks before—there was some harness stolen from the same yard where he lived—I cannot say that I suspected him more than any other person—there was inquiry made about the yard—I asked Doughton to accompany me to Smithfield, to see if we could discover it—I never charged him with being the thief—I never suspected him the least in the world.

2514.
MATILDA PALMER was indicted
for stealing 5 half-crowns and 1 shilling, the moneys of
James Turner, from his person; having been before convicted of felony.

JAMES TURNER. I live at No. 58, Newington-causeway. On the 3rd of Oct., at half-past nine o'clock at night, I saw coming along the Old Kent-road—the prisoner met me, and stopped me—I asked what she wanted—she

said, for me to treat her—I refused to do so—she still held me fast, and I tried to get rid of her—she said she wanted me to treat her with half-a-pint of ale—I went to a public-house, and called for a pint of ale—she said she would rather have some gin—we came out—still followed me, and I caught her hand in my right trowsers pocket—I had five half-crowns and one shilling in it—she stopped me for about a minute outside—she then looked round, and said, "The policeman is coming," and run as hard as she could away from me—I put my hand into my pocket, and my five half-crowns and shilling were gone—I saw her in twenty minutes or half an hour afterwards—I am certain she is the person—I had seen her a hundred times before, and knew her by sight—I told the policeman what sort of a girl she was, and he took her into custody—she asked what it was for—I said the policeman would tell her that—she said if I returned with her to her lodging, she would give me the monkey back that she had taken.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Just repeat the words she made use of. A. She said, if I would return with her, or go back to her lodging, she would give me the money she had taken—she did not say she would make it up—I am certain of her words—I asked the policeman to take notice of her worlds—she did not say, "The money you accuse me of taking"—I had been to church that evening, and I went to take a walk after—I went with the prisoner into the County tap, in the Kent-road—when the prisoner took my money she ran down a street and I lost her—she was taken but a short distance from the public-house—when we first came out of the public-house she got before me and stopped me—I pushed her aside two or three times—my money was in my right-hand trowsers pocket, which was not buttoned—I had the same coat on then that I have now—my waistcoat covers my trowsers pocket when the pocket in buttoned—I felt her have hold of my pocket two or three times—I did feel the money go—I felt in there when I paid for the gin—it was loose in my pocket—all my money went.
COURT. Q. You did not feel her take the money, but felt her hand at your pocket? A. Yes.
EDWARD CLARK (policeman, 162 P.) I took the prisoner—I told her what I wanted her for—she said, "If you will go back me to my lodging, I will give you the money I have taken"—I found 8d. on her.
LEWIS BRAY (policeman, 105 P.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 27th Oct., 1845, and confined nine months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY. Aged 23.—
Confined Seven Years.

2515.
MATHEW M'DUFF,
THOMAS FURY , and
CHARLES KEATING , were indicted for
stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the good of
John Hockham, from his person.

JOHN HOCKHAM , I reside in Broadwall, Blackfriars. On the morning of the 27th of Oct., at one o'clock in the night, I was in Stamford-street, Black-friars, with a person named Bedford, who I represented as my wife, but she was not—when near Bennett-street I felt a tug at my right-handcoat pocket—I turned, and saw my handkerchief in Fury's hand—I had used it not two minutes before—M'Duff and Keating were with him—I tried to get my handkerchief from Fury, and asked him for it—he made no answer, but gave me a violent blow in the mouth, and knocked me down—he also fell—Bedford tried to get the

handkerchief, and she was knocked down by one of the others—I got up and took my handkerchief from Fury's hand—he was on Bedford's chest—M'Duff got hold of her cloak, and Keating kicked her—I gave an alarm and the policeman came up—I gave M'Duff and Fury into custody—Keating escaped—this is my handkerchief (produced.)

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What are you? A. A general dealer—I do not know that Bedford is the wife of a person in Newgate
market—I was once in prison for an assault, five or six years ago, and had six months—that was the only time—I had not three months for robbing the poor in the City kitchen—I was employed in carrying the coals for coals for the poor—I was not punished for taking them to my own house instead of to the poor people—I have seen Fury before—I do not know that they are employed at the London News—I only know Fury by being a fighting-man—I was not perfectly sober on this night—we did not lurch against Keating—Bedford had not got hold of one of the prisoners by the neckcloth, trying to strangle him, when the others interfered to get her off—I did not strike at all; I never lifted my hand—I do not know that Mrs. Bedford was fighting with Mrs. Hawkins a night or two before this—the front of Fury's shirt was torn, I did that myself, in trying to pull him off Mrs. Bedford.

ELIZABETH BEDFORD. I pass by the name of Hockham, as the prosecu
tor's wife. About one o'clock in the morning of the 27th of Oct. I was with him in Stamford-street—just opposite Bennett-streets he turned round—I looked round, and saw Fury with this handkerchief in his hand—the other two prisoners were there—Hockham said to Fury, "That is my handkerchief; you are not going to rob me of that"—Fury up with his hand, and struck him in the face—he fell—Fury fell also, and as soon as he got up he struck me a vio
lent blow in the face, knocked me down, and knelt on me; and while I was down, M'Duff caught me by the throat, and pinched me—I said, "Oh they are throttling me!" and Keating came up and kicked me in the ribs—I be
came insensible, and do not recollect anything more for a long time—I after
wards went to the station in a cab—I was too ill to walk—I afterwards went to a surgeon—this must have occupied several minutes—I have no doubt of either of the prisoners.

Cross-examined. Q. How came you to call yourself the prosecutor's wife? A. I did not—it was he gave my name—I was too ill—I did not say my name was Elizabeth Bedford—I was not asked—I did not take hold of the front of Fury's shirt, and tear it—I do not recollect touching him—I never fought with Mrs. Hawkins—I have fought with a woman—I am not now under recognizances to keep the peace—I was once for three months, but it is twelve months ago.

JAMES BIGLIN (policeman L 133.) I heard a cry of "Police" in Stamford-street—I went to the place as quick as possible, and found all the three pri
soners and about half a dozen more—Fury was lying on his side on the ground, and Mrs. Hockham was lying on her side, insensible, by the side of him—Hockham was holding Fury, and M'Duff and Keating were standing by the side of Mrs. Hockam—M'Duff and Fury were given into custody—Keating followed us to the station, to see if they were locked up, and he tried to get bail—I tool him a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes after
wards.

Cross-examined. Q. Do not you know that the prisoners are engaged re
gularly on "the News?" A. I do not know them at all.
HENRY MARTIN (policeman, L 63.) I went to Stamford-street and found the prosecutor there, and Mrs. Hockham lying on his side, insensible—I

picked her up and held her in the air till she recovered—I then took her in a cab to the station—I saw Keating fifty or sixty yards off, but we had not hands enough to take him—he afterwards came to the station.

Cross-examined. Q. He went away for bail? A. Yes, the bail came afterwards—be came to the station of his own accord—I took the prisoners on the charge of assaulting Mrs. Hockham, and being concerned in the robbery.
MR. PARNELL. Q. What did Hockham give them in custody for? A. For picking his pocket of his handkerchief, and assaulting Mrs. Hockham.

JAMES JONES I am a surgeon, in Blackfriars-road—about two on the morning in question, Mrs. Hockham was brought to me—she was labouring under excitement—I found an abrasion just above the left hip—it might have been from a kick or fall on the kerb—the side was swollen, and the throat red, as though grasped.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

p.hi: The following Prisoners, in whose cases judgment was at the time of conviction respited, have been sentenced as under:

div0.p: Driscoll, Margaret .. .. page 44.... Confined four months.

Farr, Henry
Farr, Charles .. .. .. „ 390.... Transported for seven years.
Bradford, Mary Ann .. .. „ 505,... Confined nine months.

Doyle, Mary
M'Grath, Mary.. .. „ 1033....Confined four days
